content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												This game is a masterpiece.It is huge fun, very accessible, challenging, unique and fairly deep. If you love WH40K, Starship Troopers, RTS and/or strategy games, you will love Infested Planet.The game is simple but not simplistic. The interface is clean and effective, controlling your units is intuitive. Despite being a strategy game, the balance of action and decision-making is excellent. The complexity of the game comes from the way the various systems (simple unto themselves) combine to provide a wide variety of situations to which the player must adapt. Despite the apparently simple gameplay, there is real depth here.It is very easy to get playing. The story campaign starts with short easy missions, but ends up with massive slogs with full tech trees and hundreds of thousands of enemy casualties. You earn money to unlock new troops, techs and advantages along the way. You can emply many kinds of tactics from airstrikes to small high-tech squads with flamers and miniguns to large Imperial Guard-style meatgrinding charges.The release of the dynamic "Planetary Campaign" DLC has greatly boosted replayability. The campaign will have you saying "just one more turn" and before you know it, hours have passed. The player can choose from five map sizes and five difficulty leves. Map layout and available techs are randomized. Part of me hates this (when I don't have my favorite tech available), but part of me appreciates that this forces the player to try new things, further extending the replay factor.The graphics are fairly simple but very evocative, the sound design likewise. There are very distinctive aural clues to certain enemy types appearing, your bases being attacked, etc. When you close your eyes after a long gameplay session, you will see hordes of aliens in your mind's eye.The developer is active on the forums and responds to the community. He has continued to support and expand the game.Infested Planet is a master class on how to make a single player PC game. A clear vision, refined mechanics, trust in the players to understand and enjoy the game, customization and technical proficiency. I have not encountered a single bug (other than the millions my troops have splattered).The one thing I would wish for is mod support.Buy this game and all expansions, you will not be disappointed.

												I like this game a lot. The mechanics of the game involes a squad of 5 Marines that you can control to move to a location. content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Really digging this, it's a top-down squad level RTS - pretty much what i was actually looking for when i picked up Survivor Squad. Lots of gribblies to shoot, lots of fast-paced on-the-fly squad tinkering (you can swap out weapon loadouts instantly as you are playing between squad members) It seems silly in terms of realism, but given the pace of the game (particularly once you get to later levels or try some of the more advanced skirmish maps, which you can make as hard or easy as you want) you'll understand why. You roam the map taking down alien hives, every few you kill the enemy gets a random mutation to make things more difficult, some are awkward, some are devestating, some are pointless without other mutations, but it keeps things fresh figuring out the tech buildings you need to use or the equiptment you need to take in order to counter the new mutation.Highly recommended, i'd dearly love to see a sequel to this, preferably with an even larger and more varied tech tree to unlock with my hard earned cash - it seems a bit too easy at the moment to just grind mid-level repeatable "search and destroy" missions to unlock everything pretty fast.Absolutely worth your time, highly recommended!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												RTS games usually keep the scales relatively balanced when it comes to unit distribution. Infested Planet throws almost all of that out the window. While the aliens seem to have a happy society in place, it falls on your shoulders to disrupt it entirely and establish something much more pleasing to the obviously superior human eye. Thousands of aliens will march toward you in defense of their home, but we are determined to rid this completely non-sentient planet from its infestation. It’s not a genocide! It’s liberation! Moral questions aside, Infested Planet offers extremely unique strategic gameplay with thousands of enemies marching on almost every base relentlessly. Will it colonize your heart? Or is this game a plague? Let’s look closer at Infested Planet.Infested Planet doesn’t offer a string of interlocking building or unit upgrades, and for that I am SO grateful. Instead, rewards are offered for completing missions which can be used to purchase a variety of upgrades to your units. There are grenades, to class unlocks, along with a variety of buildings which allow you to suit your ground forces to your playstyle. Are your heavy machine-gunners a bit to slow and unwieldly to hold the entire map all by themselves? Pepper in a shot-gunners and some scouts to do the legwork. As your heavies push toward the enemy bases, perhaps you will find yourself overwhelmed again. Upgrade a couple of them to flamethrowers and watch as the swarm is beat back by a wall of flame. If all else fails, build a helipad to bring in chopper-strikes and thin the horde. The options are limitless, and all equally satisfying.Aside from picking how you want to destroy the hive during gameplay, there are also a ton of game-modes that allow you to customize HOW you want to play. One of my personal favorites features a time-limit and permadeath, which makes the impending horde that much more terrifying. The story mode features some aspects that constrict freedom of play, but I would argue that that’s what a game does. Sometimes there is a path that must be taken, the freedom still comes in the way you decide to take it. I found myself repeatedly playing missions to get the maximum amount of money possible in order to unlock the next delicious explosives-laden fruit from the tech tree. Not a necessary thing to do, but the randomized levels keep things consistently fresh.The story in this game falls quite flat, and doesn’t attempt to touch on the bevy of moral questions. The level design doesn’t seem extremely meticulous largely due to the randomized nature, but Infested Planet has certainly earned its place in my Steam library. Very few games offer enemies this endless. Your tactics need to be tight and your responses need to be on point. I supremely enjoyed the mutations of the aliens throughout the different stages, and thanks RocketBear Games very much for the review copy. I am extremely glad Infested Planet came out of Early Access with such success. This is a game that truly needs to be experienced. As you pit your squad of marines against the ravenous hordes, you will find yourself cheering them on and even mourning their little pixelated deaths.Gameplay:    Controls- 8/10    Fun Factor- 10/10    Difficulty- 8/10    Replayability- 10/10    Innovation- 8/10Aesthetic:    Graphics- 7/10    Music- 8/10    Sound FX- 7/10    Story/Lore- 3/10    Level Design- 5/10Final Score: 74/100 for fun factor, replayability, and difficulty.Summary: An absolutely massive RTS about five space-marines eliminating thousands of aliens.Verdict: Infested Planet will please RTS fans as well as anyone that enjoys truly strategic gameplay.Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-infested-planet/Full gameplay/review video: 


YouTube™ Video: Infested Planet PC Review : Alien-Stomping RTS Strategy 

			Views: 404		

			In this review we experience Infested Planet, an RTS strategy with a group of 5 marines stomping thousands of enemies. I show off some Lets Play footage before the review, and hope you will enjoy.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												A fun game with infinite replayability. Each map is randomly generated (with the exception of the campaign missions) with a starting point for your marines and however many alien hives you need to stomp into muck. As you go through a mission you need to decide how to invest your resources on the fly. You can upgrade your soldiers with different weapon classes such as flame throwers, shotguns, snipers, or a towable med station; or you build structures that enhance your soldiers with regenerating health and grenades for crowd control (which do come in handy). Another way is to leapfrog with self-building siege cannons and turrets, great for decimating hives that are close together. It is important to plan how you want to tackle each map. After defeating a hive, the aliens will mutate and gain an upgrade of their own. This may range from a spore minefield to acid howitzers to heavily armoured defenders coming at you in droves. Outside of the campaign (where you purchase upgrades between missions,) the custom mission options are pretty thorough. You can pick what kind of map, how many resources you start with, the number of hives and their potential, and more. This is great for testing out different strategies or throwing difficulty to the wind and crushing the enemy under your cannonfire and airstrikes.Bazically, if you like slaughtering near infinite numbers of aliens and adapting to the evolving horde, then I highly suggest picking this one up.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												I recommend this squad-based vs hoard game.  It's fun to play and the available strategic decisions are well-though out.  Do you get more soldiers at an ever-increasing price, give them better weapons or purchase global abilities? The mechanic of giving the aliens new abilities as you capture their points keeps battles interesting all the way through, and the ability to fully recycle resources allows flexibility so you can try different things without getting locked into a hopeless situation.  The lower difficulties are enjoyable, and the higher difficulties are challenging, yet possible.  A weekly challenge adds a psuedo-social aspect to the game.

												Hours of fun for such a low price! this game reminds me of the Old Warcraft 3 Maps where you take a group of marines and then complete objectives crossed with say bunker wars or all the footman frenzy type games highly reccomended.the replayability is quite high with randomly generated content especially when you can choose what you and the aliens can even use or mutate into.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												I recommend this squad-based vs hoard game.  It's fun to play and the available strategic decisions are well-though out.  Do you get more soldiers at an ever-increasing price, give them better weapons or purchase global abilities? The mechanic of giving the aliens new abilities as you capture their points keeps battles interesting all the way through, and the ability to fully recycle resources allows flexibility so you can try different things without getting locked into a hopeless situation.  The lower difficulties are enjoyable, and the higher difficulties are challenging, yet possible.  A weekly challenge adds a psuedo-social aspect to the game.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Pros- Good replay value, the mechanics are much like starcraft but much simpler, the difficulty is challanging and losing feels justified, units feels balanced, the game forces you to have stragety and leaves you feeling satisfiedCons- the story is interesting but feels lacking, the game requires you to think rationally or you will die a lot, The game may make you wonder what the alien's perspective is and their motivation throughtout the gameIn conclusion, this game has a great starcraft feel to it with a difficulty that will both irriate you and leave you feeling smart. The units themselves are well balanced and force you to have stragety rather then just spaming one particular unit. However the depth of the characters left me wanting more and I also felt I wanted to be apart of the alien's view as well.All in all, this is a great game that is both unique and visually pleasing. And if you enjoy playing games like starcraft but mass aliencide in the thousands is more up your alley, then this is worth every penny! 5/5 stars

Posted: March 6, 2014
												I saw a promo video for this when it was in beta and decided I'd go over my limit for the number of early access/betas I buy into. That is a choice I've not regretted, there's been a great suggestions thread on the forums thats worth a wander through to give you an idea of what has been developed off the back of community suggestions and how willing the dev is to consider ideas.At first glance it's a fairly simple squad based rts and it is just that. However there are mutations to consider and those are randomised so each hive you capture you have to adjust your tactic to counter stuff like longer range on enemy turrets to different alien types. Another simple mechanic but one that can sometimes turn a map from a walk in the park to more of a fight.Alongside the campaign, which has good variety in the missions being done, are skirmish modes and weekly challenge maps of differing difficulty. Highly reccomned this

Posted: February 14, 2014
												Very addictive game! The developer puts alot of effort in this game and listens to the community.Overall a great game that sucks up a few of your gaming hours, but well spent!Gameplay: 9Graphics: 8Sound: 7Replay value: 9

Posted: February 15, 2014
												If you like the free game "attack of the paper zombies" (http://www.indiebird.com/blog/?page_id=376) you'll love Infested Planet (IP).I think of IP as a roguelite RTS. You control a small set of soldiers, vie for control points with an AI alien swarm enemy, get awarded resource points, spend then on your soliders, or use them to build base defences or support for your team. If you dont like how youve spent your resource points you can refund them instantly for full value (which means you can try multiple tactics without penalty - I think this is better than what I recall in AOTPZ). As you capture more contorl points and push back the aliens the remaining ones get random upgrades which dynamically makes them harder to fight, meaning you might need ot change your (previously) winning tactics - its a great mechanic.Its expertly put together, featuring a campaign (with fixed maps) and two different types of randomly generated skirmishes with varying difficulty.  Controls, graphics, animations, etc are all great. My only criticism is the wording of the "single mission use" unlocks - these actually appear to unlock a "single upgrade" for use on any mission - making them much more valable than what I understood them to be (I thought it was use it and then lose it). As it was, I played through the game without them, which was much harder than it would have been with them.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												100% recommend. This is a game with a singular vision - RTS tactics versus an alien horde - that is executed perfectly. The UI, the graphics, the carefully crafted difficulty curve, all combine to make a game that feels like the platonic ideal of TACTICS. The campaign grows in difficulty in a way that forces you to learn and adapt your strategy, and the core gameplay loop of attack, stabilize, repeat remains consistently satisfying. Each step up in difficulty demands more efficiency and mastery of your tools while feeling relatively fair. There's a lot of content if you find the gameplay compelling. A decently long campaign teaches you how to play reasonably competently, and random levels stay fresh with the random enemy mutations that occur as you capture territory during the level. There's also the now-customary feature of weekly challenge levels with leaderboards.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Great indie gem that is easily worth the price. While the strategies to win the game aren't especially deep, it is fun unlocking more advanced tech as you go and reaching that point of having access to the best weapons, buildings, and abilities. A great strength of Infested Planet is how adaptable your forces are. You can swap the weapon type / class of a soldier (or even dismiss a soldier) at any time without losing any permanant resources (if you swap to a cheaper weapon you get a refund for the difference, etc...). This applies to auto-turrets, mine fields, buildings, etc... as well. Often times the aliens will spawn a mutation that forces you to react by changing your squad loadout on the fly, so it is great that the devs allow you to do just that. It is a game that rewards both light strategic thinking and quick tactical decision making on the fly.The only thing that would make the game better imo is some kind of RPG system where your squad members could carry over between maps. With proper management they're no more likely to die in this than they are in XCOM (abuse that teleport!). As it is your squaddies are entirely generic from map to map and even death to death. If nothing else, a neat touch could be keeping count of how many aliens a specific marine had killed in a battle / campaign :)

Posted: November 8, 2015
												Even if I cannot properly play RTS due to frantic multitasking, I enjoyed the first missions of Infested Planet. It's hard to do a fair review of the game since the pressure was too hard to actually explore all the options the game had to offer (unlike classical TD)One interesting aspect of the game is that the alien nests have spawn blobs and tower with a visible range, so if you're cautious enough, you may approach your target being undetected (otherwise, a steady flow of critters will converge to you).Another design aspect of the game is that the alien behavior clearly looks like liquid flow, so it sometimes appears you're dealing with rivers going wild (or plumbing issues). I feel there is some kind of hidden gameplay here, but wasn't able to access it.All in all : a good RTS if you appreciate being pressured from all sides ;)

Posted: May 15, 2016
												Incredible game. Pretty simple on the face of it. You kill alien hordes that look like gigantic insect colonies. Imagine one of those solo Starcraft II missions where you're a small band of marines going around and killing bases. It's like that but a full game built around it.This game isn't too hard but some of the hardest missions will put you up against literally thousands of creatures inching their way to your base. Dying is the result of either poor management or overzealousness. The game is mostly about controlling the flow of "insects", demolishing bases that create these creatures, and preventing your base from being overcome. Infested Planet does a good job of slowly introducing new gameplay mechanics and features. The variety of missions is pretty enough. Simply hearing the sound of a hearing an alien base explode is entertaining enough.While pretty fun from start to finish the final levels can get a little redundant. I wish the game really pushed it to the extremes even though it's already quite the beast. I haven't yet played the DLC, but I look forward to a Steam sale in the future. I hope a sequel is in the works with even more badass enemies and military classes.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												A very fun and tactical RTS. Command a group of soldiers against a practically infinite horde of alliens. You have the advantage of technology, firepower and a tactical mind vs ridiculous numbers. If that premise sounds great you should be buying this game now.The game is more about tactical combat and less about resources, you can always salvage whatever you have used and get something else to switch up your strategy if the current one isn't working and your resource cap is always the same, so you do not need to worry that much about experimenting with different unit types. Still the game provides a challenge, the alliens get more varied and with upgrades of their own to keep up the pace with your troops, occasionally throwing special enemies at you as well to keep you on your toes.Definitely the most tactics oriented RTS I recall seeing. Graphics are great and do their job, gameplay is quick and smooth in easy missions and a gruelling slow trench war in the harder ones. There's both challenge here and satisfaction in outmanuevering and destroying a more powerful foe.Very much recommended.

Posted: June 19, 2015
 Really fun RTS  This review is based on the base game and the Trickster's Arsenal DLC This game is pretty fantastic, it's really unique and fun. It feels very good to take over a base, destroy aliens with airstrikes and much more.   The goal is to destroy and replace all the enemys bases (hives) with the space marine-guys own bases. To your help you have:  Buildings  that can be placed anywhere on the map, for example siege turrets, usual turrets and shields.  Abilities  which are temporary benefits like a cluster-grenade attack and 4 riflemen that can be dropped anywhere but last for 30 seconds.  Tech  , which mostly are upgrades to the soldiers, like grenades and and spawning at the front instead of at your own base when they die and more. Weapons  that you buy for one specific soldier, and are permanent, for example flame throwers, sniper rifles and miniguns. There's also some nice advantages that the soldier gets with the weapon, like a personal shield or invisibility.   There's two different resources in the game - BP and ammo. BP's are earned when taking over the enemy's bases or getting specific crates to your own base and are spent on tech, buildings, new mariens and weapons. Ammo is slowly regenerating, but can be instantly gained from dragging ammo crates to your base and is used for temporary abilities, mortars and the marines rocket launchers does also use them.   The amount of different tech, weapons, abilities and buildings means the game allows for many different tactics and play-styles, and since there isn't a punishment for refunding the things earlier purchased, one can change the tactic completely mid-game, for example from like two guys with three of the very effective siege turrets to four guys wielding miniguns and throwing grenades.   All this stuff might sound a bit over powered, but the aliens does also gain some really nasty stuff, called "mutations". Cloning marines when they die, increasing the damage and range of their turrets a lot and spawning some really tough aliens that then settle down and in turn begins to spawn regular aliens, just to name a few.   I think that this - overall - is a really good game, and I do also recommend the DLC if you like the base game.

You don't just grind away until you are over powered and sweep the map. You constantly struggle to stem the tide, and as soon as you make some progress a new mutation sends you realing.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												Definetly one of the most refreshing, straight to action, rts out there. No base building, resource gathering, just simple action with upgrade. content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												This was a great deal of fun if you really enjoy the tactical RTS genre. You command a squad of 5 or so marines that try to accomplish certain objectives, usually capturing alien bases, as you capture bases or capture resource crates you can upgrade your marines to different attack types or build upgrade buildings (equivalent of researching upgrades).  It was a lot of fun figuring out the mechanics of the system and how to manage your resources, then trying out different tactics to capture the alien hives (bases).  As you progress in the game, the aliens 'mutate' different abilities to keep you on your toes. If you are not paying attention that 'burrowing hive' ability may have popped up a hive behind your front line and is now in ur base killin ur barracks.  If you get really stuck, you can buy upgrades to start with for a single mission with in game money. I kept playing after I finished the story campaign to knock out all the acheivements. All in all roughly 25 hours of play, including farming money to tackle the last 'Raid' mission acheivement. A few quick tips for the later levels after you read the guides. Try to always attack hives with at least one Flamer in the group One officer and a minigunner are REALLY handy for tackling late level raids/missions where hives are clustered 3-4 at once. Keep moving one to the next. Keep the mini focused on the hive, it will eat through any shielding easily, while the flamer distracts the towers, and the marine(s) protect the mini.  Don't be afraid to switch your classes around, change them to scout to sneak really fast to a spot (Like back to defend a base), then switch them to minigunner or whatever.   Keep an eye on your map and the mutations in play. Be ready to defend against burrowers, or tower spawners, or if you see a squad of clones/mimics be sure to change one of your people to a sniper (for Minigunners) or scout.  Life support > Medic pod. Medic pod only heals ONE person at a time near it, Life Support for only one or two points more heals EVERYTHING (buildings) and everyone.  Marine>turret. If you need to defend a spot, try to use mines. They never run out, and are effective against almost EVERYTHING.  If not, use a marine, they are much more versatile.  Turrets are expensive and die quickly in middle/late levels, you better have Engineering to autorebuild it by then.  Engineering is a tactician's dream. You can pop offensive mines, build or recycle anything, anywhere on the map.  In EVERY game mode other than raid, take advantage of the fact that the hives won't mutate until you start capturing. Go sneak a scout and steal all the crates, kill defenders with grenades, if you die, keep inching the crates in and then switch your scout to something else before you begin your attack.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I bought this game during the steam sale not really expecting much but I was pleasantly surprised at how deep and difficult the game is. The game plays like starcraft tower defense games of old. With you micromanaging a team of units to go kill towers that spawn enemies continuously. You upgrade your guys and build things to make the killing go  easier. I honestly wasn't expecting too much from such a cheap game but the final few missions were very difficult.After getting past the somewhat janky interface to move your units the gameplay blends pretty well. I wish there was a minimap so that I could get a proper birds eye view of the battle field rather than needing to zoom out. The game does have its issues though, Money is not all that important once you've purchased all the upgrades since you would only spend it on consumables. The shotgun is also exceedingly strong and works for pretty much every situation so there was little desire to go beyond officers and shotguns when deciding your team buildup. The enemy also gets random mutations which make certain fights easy and certain fights tedious.However despite all the issues the game is solid and if it was on sale for as cheap as during the steam sale definetly look into buying it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												This is the game I have been waiting for.This is a game made by people who stopped and thought about what makes games good... and what doesn't.  Nothing unneccisary was added; no gimmick mechanics, no "surprise!" changing of the rules.  Everything is straight forward, in your face, down your throat awesome.This game is made of win.What you can expect:A game that plays by the rules.  HARD rules, yes... but still, by the rules.Progressive difficulties that build on what you've previously seen/learned.Devs who give you the option to play like a pro... or grind out extra cash for that edge you might need for your inner casual to sit back and kill some pixels.No shoe-horned solutions (see below)This game is the perfect mix of frantic and tactical.  You'll find yourself pausing, issuing orders, and then madly darting around the screen trying to handle three or more fronts at once as a new mutation puts you on the ropes.  And no matter how bad it gets, no matter how harsh the mutation roullette wheel grinds you down... it's... still... fun.So how many ways can you skin the provervial cat?You like cannons?  Build cannons to hold back the horde while you slowly chip away at them.You like deep strikes?  Build helicoptors and double your ammo supply to nuke bases with three consecutive waves of heli-strikes.You like tech?  Build some healing pods to keep your troops up.  Hell, son... let's stick some tech IN our troops and make them faster, stronger, better... that's right, the 6 BP Man!You like fighting swarms with swarms?  Make.  More.  Troops.  Make ALL THE TROOPS!  Don't even spend money on guns, just make... more... troops!  And then LET LOOSE THE HOUNDS OF WAR!And all of that?  Those are just SOME of the ways I've beaten... THE SAME LEVEL.  That's right... any tactic you can afford (BP's pretty thin if you don't think things through)... can be made to work.  In fact, that tactic you just tried and failed?  It might just be you went in the wrong order.  Did you spread yourself too thin?  Forget to backfill some defenses?  Did you recycle your old swag and move it forward?  Oh... did you get that one mutation you don't have defenses for?  Well... TRY IT AGAIN!I rarely rave over a game... but in the last few years I've seen so much schlock, so many shiny letdowns... to have finally been given a chance to enjoy game that doesn't 'try'... it just succeeds.If you like real time strategy games, go find a Let's Play for this game.  I'll bet you press the buy now button before the video's over.  I did.  And I have no regrets.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												This is a great game, probably my favourite RTS. Solid gameplay where you take a squad of marines around destroying aliens and their hives, but combined with some tower defence elements where you protect your own bases or the chokepoints leading to them and upgrade your abilities. The interface is crisp and well thought-out, it's well-balanced with the marine types and upgrades, and it's kept interesting by the aliens mutating to adapt to your tactics, but you can also always recycle everything to change your tactics accordingly. It also has great sound effects. Tactical and fun - you can't go wrong for the price.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												I had played the predecessor to this game before, "Attack of the Paper Zombies", and enjoyed it a lot despite me not being a big RTS fan. I couldn't really stand the slower pace of most RTS's, so the faster pace of this game is probably one of the main things that drew me to it. In "Infested Planet", you command a squad of soldiers and try to destroy alien nests, reclaim bases, while at the same time protecting yours. You will aquire "BP", which you cans spend on upgrades for your troops, build structures to assist you, or add more soldiers. Levels start out realtively easy, but quickly become more frantic and crazy as the game progresses. Besides the campaign, there are also weekly challenges and randomly generated levels of varying difficulty. There is a bit randomness to the game that forces you to think on your toes, while not feeling unfair at the same time. All in all, for a game still in Beta, I've been having a ton of fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												I enjoyed this game a lot! It's really exactly what it promised in the trailer. I don't think it's worth the regular price but in sale it's a good buy. It really had a Starcraft-like Terran vs Zerg vibe, down to even the loading screens being very reminiscent of that series. Didn't bother me, but it could bother others.Pros Fun gameplay, requiring tactical decisions Easy to pick up, no steep learning curve Upgrade system with valuable upgrades that change your playstyleCons Few things are actually explained decently. For example, I didn't know snipers were a good idea against towers, as they are "advertised" as being good vs units but can't damage structures. I didn't like the graphics, and they weren't very diverse. There's a green and a purple palette and that's about it. Dialogue wasn't voiced and that gave the storyline characters a trivial feeling. It felt like they were there to give some diversity and reasoning to the maps but I really didn't feel invested in any of the characters. In fact, that leads to my next point.. The storyline isn't so good altogether. I won't spoil anything but it's nothing spectacular The game gets pretty tough later in the campaign mode, increasing difficulty by creating "unfair" advantages for the enemy player. I don't think that's the right way to increase difficulty. I would have liked to see more diverse monsters or challenges in the landscape. This game lacks online co-op play! That would've been awesome.  You should definitely pick this up if the trailer appeals to you gameplay-wise. Other than that there's not much more to be found in this game, but that point alone is good enough to carry it to a positive review!

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Squad-based-mini-rts-swarm game that simply delivers.The player has a significant choice of tactics, depending on his style of play and the situation. And the situations changes dynamically.The enemy, a quickly mutating alien swarm, has the unpredictable ability to generate different abilities when you strike a blow at their hive. Different mutations can form a deadly combination, which will force you to quickly rearrange your plan to be able to hold your ground.At the point of this review I have played 14 hours, 12 of which on the Skirmish mode and each game delivers different experience.It nudges you to plan, adapt and think on your feet. For a casual game where you can dive for a 20 min game, it is extremely well done. You can see the polish in the little details, animations, and lack of even minor bugs, which many AAA class games have.I recommend.Also, keep an eye out at Alex. This guy seems to get what game balance means in each form of the phrase – fun, choice, fairness, reward.

												It was fun up until the end. I will keep this simple, learning the game was fun, step by step, actually playing it was a pain and rather boring, uneventful and same hat. Not much strategy involved, other than protecting your structures with turrets and killing high priority targets before they spawn more enemy bases. Other than that, nothing really.Pros+ Fast paced+ Simple, bare minimal strategy+ "Bought when it was cheap"Cons- Boring- Same enemies- Same situation - Same tactics- No real challenging strategy involved- Boring graphics, on par' with creeper world- Not worth at full priceConclusionIt's worth the price, "IF" it's reduced. Don't buy it at full price as with most iffy quality games. A simple shooter, team, strategy base game. Nothing more than that, no gimmacks, nothing special about it, same old boring, bare bones hat tricks. Stay AWAY if it's full priced.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												More a tedious, stressful and relentless masochistic experiment than a true entertaining game.All is : "find the way mission is supposed to be played to win".As mission start you have to RUN with the proper sequence / build order in order to succeed.So you have to fail / retry as long as you don't find the way it supposed to be played (AKA puzzle game and not RTS).Simply NO FUN. You have no freedom in your playstyle.Sorry but Fun is the major reason to play games for me. Challenge ? Oh yes ! But don't mismatch challenge with stressful punishing experience.The more you go into campaign, the less flexibility you have in your playstyle.Do this quick, do that now, click here and there NOW  or 'the doctor will die' etc... No creation, no self decision, just execute the proper sequence. Pretty decent graphics and atmosphere, but a true deception for me because its lack of fun. Overall : 4 / 10

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												So what is Infested Planet like?It's rather good. It mixes squad based tactical gameplay with somewhat conservative base building RTS, and throws in swarms and swarms of aliens.


YouTube™ Video: Infested Planet - Mac Gameplay 

			Views: 264		

			An indie tactical squad based strategy game, where you fight off swarm of aliens. Click Here To Subscribe  http://bit.ly/19ksM1a Infested Planet  http://store.steampowered.com/app/204530 Twitter ...		

The game starts you off nice and easy, and then quickly progresses in difficulty. Sometimes getting you stuck because you happened to spend build points on the wrong upgrade or building. Before you realise it you're bang eaten alive by a swarm of alien larva.It's very fun, and it's rare for me to sit down and just play a game for over an hour these day, before wanting to do something else.Focussing mostly on your small squad of tactical marines, it can become very challenging juggling between them for attacking, defending and trying to do some base building at the same time.Upgrades are essentially, and the game has a very simple and nice way of managing them. They're acquired through plain old money, earned through missions. Which are either Story based ones, or Random missions, that only seem to serve as ways to get money and much needed upgrades.I would easily recommend this game for people that like squad based RTS games, and it's as close to a Starship Troopers squad RTS as you're going to get.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												New Review 20 March 2014: I didn't think it was fair to keep my old review, nor fair to the players to read the old review if it was no longer relevant information. I will, however, keep it on here as a reminder of how far along Infested Planet has come.Infested Planet is a top down RTS game that combines mobile tower defense with a king-of-the-hill aspect. The development team has come a long way in a short time (a few months) since my last post. They have been doing a lot of hard work to create a challenging and fair environment for the players.The later missions are very difficult, putting your knowledge of the various units to the test. In order to complete them you will have to combine a number of different tech buildings and unit types in order to overcome the various enemies.In-game unit details are not amazing, but they are informative. When you hover your cursor over a tech it will give you generalized information on what the unit does, including the hotkey it is assigned too. For instance, the officer unit tells you that after 'destroying a hive units gain %200 attack speed' but it does not tell you how long the buff lasts. You'll just have to become familiar with the units yourself, knowing their capabilities.When completing missions you will be awarded cash/credits/money based on a set value or a number of factors including how well you did. This cash is used in the out-of-game shop menu in order to purchase different tech/units to use in game. The shop also has additional units or unit buffs for the next match you play, increasing your chance of winning by giving you more/better units.Skirmishes are now balanced and fair for the player. The new code checks the map for specific variables which gives the player a fair start. This allows for a challenging experience from beginner to master.Over all, Infested Planet has come a long way since its beta period.8 out of 10.-KamlynOld Review: Infested planet is not a bad "flash game" because that's basically what it is. You play top down and control a squad to defend points and take points, much like king of the hill meets mobile tower defense. It's not bad, but I honestly think it needs some balancing. The randomized skirmish maps can easily make completing it a piece of cake, or a two hour long slug fest which results in a loss. I find a lot of the "Research/Tech" buildings to be completely useless, costing too many bonus points in a match to really be able to build unless your steam rolling in which case you don’t need them anyway. Without purchasing "Free Buffs/Units" from the shop the later levels are extremely difficult to complete which is good if your looking for a hardcore challenge. Infested Planet is regularly patched but is considered a final release, so small things will change here and there. IMHO, I also think the "Free Buff/Unit" shop purchases need to be removed. Maybe an experience bar instead of a cash inflow to unlock your research, this way there would also be no excess "money".-EDIT: After additional playing and reading of others reviews and partial guides (aka. better explained unit abilities, which I think Infested Planet needs a complete page for itself. Properly explaining units and there abilities full effects) I conclude that with proper use of units and strategy can lead to a satisfying result (A win, or a "did-your-best" loss).-EDIT 14 Jan 2014: There has been a change in the unit lineup. Your all useful medic has been removed, and this techno box thing with medic capabilities (which can be towed by a unit) has replaced it! The Medic Box costs 5 BP instead of 6BP, making it cheaper, but I find that it is: much easier to destroy, increases micro required, and even further decreased my enjoyment of Infested Planet. The medic was replaced by the officer upgrade, and I find that it seriously lacks. The officer inspires your units to do better by moving faster. he only increases your units rate of fire IF they KILL A HIVE. Why doesn't he just give a passive bonus since he's inspiring them? If you cant tell this is a bias edit. I really enjoyed the medic as a unit and now I'm left with this easy to destroy thing. FIXED-BUG: Don't forget to change your hotkeys otherwise you won't be able to quickly build the Medic Box. Even after setting my hotkeys I couldn't easily build it, and was FORCED to left click the buff... -EDIT 28 Jan 2014, Patch 14: With the new patch 14 out it gives me some hope. Although I have not yet had the time to play around in patch 14, it looks as though it has fixed a few issues I had been having with the pervious partial patch. Will update post when I've had a chance to play.-EDIT 20 March 2014: So I took a vacation from Infested Planet in order to allow the Dev's time to implement a lot of patching instead of one or two and ranting on a small change. As a Dev has so graciously posted in my review I would like to go over the recent changes which has made me enjoy Infested Planet more than I previously did (See beginning of review).8 out of 10 stars,-Kamlyn

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Infested Planet was a mildly diverting RTS-lite game with that age-old science fiction narrative about space marines killing alien bugs on an unforgiving uninhabited world.Yes, I played the campaign all the way through. Yes, I beat the bugs. Yes, I had fun... but I wouldn't recommend you spend the money to have the same experience.While the variety of upgrades and abilities available in the game was interesting and diverse, the combat pacing and the manner in which you had to almost constantly be pushing for new capture points in order to a) actually achieve anything other than a gooey stalemate with the bugs and b) actually gain the resources you needed to buy cooler toys for your grunts meant that I figured out one or two pretty comfortable strats about halfway through the campaign and... just didn't feel the need to experiment. Scarcity of resources and a high value placed on individual marines means that your options are pretty limited; turrets simply weren't cost-effective in my experience so most of the time I stationed lone rifle marines at choke points while pushing hives with the remaining 4 or 5 marines that I actually had resources to buy better weapons for. Gameplay was a little tactically rewarding, but gets a little stale when it's almost the same scenario over and over and over and too many of the enemy "mutation" modifiers are just frustratingly unfun.Go ahead and give Infested Planet a chance if you want, but my personal recommendation is that you go play StarCraft again instead.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Mindless killing of mindless hordes if you want an evening of mindless (not some much you do have to think a little) gaming. But seriously it’s what it says on the packaging, you grab a squad progress through the level, normally destroying alien nests while killing thousands of bugs who want to eat your squad. Between missions you upgrade your squads gear, new weapons or options and progress to the next level. This is one of the games where you want some fun but don’t want anything serious (detailed background, griping story, open world etc.). If you want a game of that elk, then this is for you, if you want something with a bit more up then seriously consider the purchase, thumbs up from me!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Great game, fun & juicy aesthetic with solid mechanics/game design.Some puzzle/small scale rts/tower defense+offense mechanics.Each level you're attempting to solve which troop types/buildings/tactics will work against the situation. You must do this through spending your command points on upgrades/troops etc. The thing that makes this game so fun & better than the others in this genre is that anything you buy will be refunded for 100% of the purchase value (in command points) .... so just because you've made a bad purchase, you can still come back and recover provided you haven't lost a bunch of bases and cascaded toward failure too far. This rewarding of experimentation provides the same level of strategy/tactical thought as other games of smiliar genre ... but you just end up having to reset the game a lot less.

												Incredibly addictive and fun! The variety of units and tactical combincations are just enough to keep it fresh each challange and the mutation changes really keep you on your toes. Really simply mechanics, but great tactical depth.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I'm convinced that most real-time strategy games shouldn't bother with an actual lore and storyline. The ones with better storylines usually crib their source material from conflicts in history, and I usually gloss over those because there's a sense of THIS IS ROOTED IN HISTORY, IT'S LIKE I'M ACTUALLY THERE via gameplay (what I like to call the Saving Private Ryan approach). Beyond that... oh Christ. The Dawn of War series comes to mind as my first go-to answer for why RTS games shouldn't bother, largely because Warhammer (40K and otherwise) is a gigantic batch of poorly written juvenile♥♥♥♥♥♥with all the depth and appeal of a moody teenager sitting in a dark room slapping the dolls from all of his Collector's Edition video games together. ("Anything by Blizzard" is an immediate runner-up, mainly because Blizzard rips off Warhammer lock, stock, and barrel and any attempt I've made to read any lore for one of their universes made me wish I hadn't.). Infested Planet ALMOST sidesteps this.Infested Planet is a wonderful distillation of the real-time strategy genre. It pares the structure of a typical RTS down to a few buildings, a few soldiers, and the ability to instantly change your soldiers and abilities on the fly. The enemy is entrenched and reacts to upgrade itself, and sometimes you'll find that the strategy you're employing won't work at all in the face of shielded buildings and mimic squads that copy your squad exactly to kill your own soldiers. And even if the enemy succeeds in kicking your♥♥♥♥♥and taking your bases, you can refund your previously built kit and try a new strategy. The enemy captured your siege cannon? No prob, just switch a grunt from a sniper to a scout and have that scout weaken the building while the rest of the squad puts lots of bullets in it. Want to destroy a series of hives and then set up an area to protect your new base of operations? Go with an officer and four minigunners, kill them all, then switch to shotgunners and flamethrowers and spend the rest of your resources on defense encampments. It's a wonderful game that allows and forces players adapt to unforseen developments (and there are plenty of those that the enemy is willing to pull out in order to destroy your dumb little squad of soldiers).If you're going to play it, however, I recommend that you play the campaign up to a point, because that's where the game keeps the 'random' missions. The campaign is almost where I fell out of love with Infested Planet. Not just because I have to play something I don't want to play to unlock features inside the game, but also because the campaign's learning and difficulty curve moves up too slowly, and it also keeps taking away the focus from the free-wheeling dance of terror with a plodding story about an army that invades a bug-infested planet and then the planet fights back and then the bugs kill the army and then the stranded sexy female scientist pulls out a bioweapon and the big bug hivemind is destroyed in the last mission and it is told with the same amount of care and excitement employed in this run-on sentence. A lot of the included campaign is boring and stifles what makes this game great. Infested Planet doesn't need a campaign mode and a cast of characters talking over soldiers shooting alien bugs to 'flesh out the lore' (but if the developers insist, get someone who can actually write this sort of thing). Infested Planet's magic lies in its skirmishes and random missions.

												Mindless killing of mindless hordes if you want an evening of mindless (not some much you do have to think a little) gaming. But seriously it’s what it says on the packaging, you grab a squad progress through the level, normally destroying alien nests while killing thousands of bugs who want to eat your squad. Between missions you upgrade your squads gear, new weapons or options and progress to the next level. This is one of the games where you want some fun but don’t want anything serious (detailed background, griping story, open world etc.). If you want a game of that elk, then this is for you, if you want something with a bit more up then seriously consider the purchase, thumbs up from me!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												A great game that I cannot reccomend enough. I bought it on a whim this afternoon when I wanted something new, and Steam recommended this based on a game I've got nearly 300 hours logged on (100 in the last 2 weeks). I've basically played this for 6 hours straight now, and if I didn't have to get up for work in the morning, I'd probably do another 6 happily.Interface is so intuitive that there's virtually no tutorial. You can look key bindings up and there are tooltips on controls that tell you them too. Its a game thats fast enough to keep your brain active, but laid back enough that you can watch or listen to something else at the same time. Some missions are randomly generated, so that gives a lot of replayability, and there is a great spectrum of difficulty and types.The basic principal of every level is "destroy the bug hives", but so far I've hit 3 principals. One is your standard story mission, not much to explain there, its the plotline. The second is a kind of time trial mode - you start with a clock, when it runs out, you're done. The more bugs you kill, the more you get paid. Every time you take out a hive, you get more time, and if you clear them all, then you get bonus pay. The last type is a standard annihilation mission, but almost every time you take out a hive, the aliens mutate (effects are very varied, from upping their counter attack speed when you take a hive location to aliens that spawn towers when they die, hives fighting back directly, etc). So far, I've not even cleared the second tier of that level because while an individual hive isn't too challenging to take down (though it is a real meat grinder), its when you hit groups of 3 hives at once that things get interesting. I've sent air strikes, cluster bombs and my entire squad at them and the best I can get so far is a meat grinder where neither of us win.Best money I've spent on a game in a long time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												OLD REVIEW: This game feels like a really lite version of Starcraft, which isn't a bad thing.  It's really easy to pick up, and is a lot of fun. I'd thoroughly recommend it for full price. If it's on sale, it's an even better deal.I've been reworking some of my reviews, to be slightly better. As you can see above, my original review was pretty uninformative. So when I think of this game, I think of it as a Starcraft Lite. What I mean when I say this is Starcraft is a very skill heavy RTS game; it has kind of a high skill floor. Infested Planet does not. It's a top down RTS that's very simple. You start with a base and a few marines, and some money to spend on the marines or your base. Your objective is to capture all the points on the map (usually, campaign stuff varies). You'll have to kill the bugs in your way to do that. To do this, you can upgrade your units via indirect upgrades (buildings that upgrade your marines) or directly upgrade your marines. You can spend money to change your starting marine from a marine to a flame trooper, or a scout, or a shotgunner. From there, you can send your marines to their death, just to have them respawn in roughly 10 seconds. Your army constantly replenishes. If you have 5 marines, and they all die, they'll respawn at the nearest control point after a short timer. They keep their classes and everything. So marines dying really isn't that big of a deal. If you also decide you don't like building A, and you don't like that the one marine is a flame trooper, you can refund both, and get all your money back. The game is very flexible, in regards to what you can quickly do to change your strategies. There are also commander abilities you can use by using commander points. Commander points slowly come back, or you can pick up items in the game that refresh it. The abilities all do different things, like a helicopter strike. All of them can be incredibly useful, depending on your end goal. This game also has dlc that adds some more abilities for you to use. I bought it for $2.50 and it was totally worth it. If you want a simple but fun RTS, I'd highly recommend picking up this game. It's a good bargain at the price.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												This game is going to take hours from your life.At first, you're going to be all 'Ha!  Stupid alien freaks, meet my sentry turret while I flank your position and rinse you...', but then you're going ton be all, 'Oh, that's how it's going to be, is it?  Well, I'll just take this position and upgrade this to that and then I'll come right up there and I'll cough on your sandwiches.'But that's just the easy parts... oh yes...It's when you get to the part where yoiu're screaming at your troops,'Hold the line, DAMNIT!  HOLD THE LINE!!!' or 'What the heck did that wee freak do?  Are they all armoured?  How fast?' till there's a little something left over in your brain that says, 'Dear Satan they're coming and there's nothing that's goign to stop them this time... nothing...'This has given me so much satisfaction and so much joy as a tactical top-down strategy game that I have reinstalled it over and over.  I just have to keep going back to it.  And that, for me, is the standard of an EPIC game.  It does look pretty, but keeps it simple, the soundtrack is limited, but then that's alright - you really won't be paying that much attention to the music, and the engine is smooth and robust, especially given how many units can be on the feild at any one given time with a dozen mutators all in effect.Get this game and prepare to have your own Aliens / Starship Troopers 'They sucked his brains out' experience...FOR REAL!  ;)

												The trailer told me to kill aliens.I killed aliens.A lot of aliens.Seriously there are so many aliens you should buy it just for that, as much as I'd like to I can't get rid of 'em all just by myself.^And to add at least one serious point to this review, I love the fact that you can't just sit around and turtle with your units (In the horde or survival modes anyway) as the aliens just keep building up and mutating... because of that you simply can't keep defending with a limited amount of resources no matter how much fire or bullets you have.To really play the game properly you have to stay mobile, or at least venture outside of wherever you've set up your base to destroy alien hives, collect more resources, spend resources... rinse and repeat... forever... or y'know, just die.

												Being a big Starcraft 1 fan, This game gave me back the hope that blizzard had crushed. That and this game hasn't tried to pickpocket my credit card so major plus there!-----------The has a feel of starcraft but it's a game of it's own.It's a simple real-time strategy with elements that have a homely feel to it, there is no real base building or resource gather instead you capture infested bases which in turn give points, these points pretty much are your resource which you can use to buy marines, turrets, perks, etc.Sorry for not giving a complete review as you can see I haven't played much of it(I'm lazy, I'm ADD and I sleep more then play games lol, that or I'm busy moderating my friends stream)Once I beat the game I'll give a better review.+--------+Downvote me if you think I'm handsome ;3

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												Considering that the sight of the ocean fills Kiwi with mortal terror, he has never actually seen a surfboard, let alone gone surfing. What research Kiwi could bring himself to perform suggest that this game is quite an accurate simulation of the sport of surfing. As if maintaining balance to avoid the ocean's deadly embrace isn't enough, there are the varying tides and many tricky waves that will try to pull you into the abyss. But to merely survive is not enough, you must also out-do your fellow aqua-braving madmen in what death-defying stunts you can do on your sliver of safety.As you progress through the games story, even more dangers are placed in your path: sharks, other less alert, but infinitely better balanced surfers, and your own mermaid clones. The latter, Kiwi assumes, is the result of the mermaids stealing your DNA during one of your many "wipe outs." Some may suggest that it'd be more appropriate to call them mer-people, but that's silly. Any one who's studied the English language knows that the correct way to refer to the collective of them is "mermaids." Their ability to clone you implies many unpleasant things about the aquatic civilization, not least among them is a lack of laws against identity theft. Unfortunately, these implications are not explored in the game's story, most likely the developers plan to revist it in the sequel.

												I only recommend it if you can get it for less than 10$. Nice concept in general, a mix of RTS and tower defense.  But it does get quite repetitive over time, especially since theres no multiplayer option.Also it needs a lot more balancing, some weapons and tech are either totally overpowered or totally useless. content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												There is a TL;DR (too long, didn't read) at the end of each paragraph.The Game *campaign*: starts off pretty good. Small tutorial basically tells you to take your guys, move them forward, kill stuff. easy matches no problem until right around mission 7 - 8 regardless of whether it's a story mission or the random missions,♥♥♥♥♥♥goes to hell way too quick. You go from: Oh hey, this is easy im having a good time to: wait what the ♥♥♥♥? Why can't I kill one building? Why is everything dying? I built everything or upgraded everything and im still getting pushed through? The difficulty goes from 1 to 100 way too quick. Some missions, if you don't build PERFECTLY or follow a strict guideline you WILL fail. Some of the alien mutations become WAY too hard to fight. It would probably be better if you gained Build Points over time, or if they gave you more for doing certain things, but overall this game sucks. There's no difficulty settings, and some missions litterlly depend on RNG. Whether or not the AI wants to send massive amounts of aliens to kill you, or just sit back and wait while you slowly struggle to kill the bases. Whether they get insane defensive mutations, or just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ones like visible landmines that any solider can destroy at any time.TL;DR:- Campaign goes from easy to bat♥♥♥♥♥♥crazy way too fast -- No difficulty settings -- No room for error -- not enough resources - The Units Part 1: Starts off with rifflemen, which can take care of pretty much everything unless there is a giant swarm of somekind, and not so great against buildings (turrets). The shotgun guys come in on mission two, which makes crowd control SO much better and a lot more fun, but in the same match you notice something that will cause you immediate brain sufferage, Turrets. High range and damage, never miss. But here's the thing. They Also do damage over time AND SLOW DOWN your units movement speed. TL;DR- Fun early game crowd control units -- ♥♥♥♥ turrets -Upgrades part 1:At this point you're probably thinking, well how bad could it be? first mission *mission two* with turrets, I only lost a guy or two, and i get infinite respawns without consequences, it's fine. The game brings you to your first screen in-between missions where you can buy upgrades. The Very first thing I notice? "Single Mission Exhaustible Powerup" I'm like wait, the first thing I can afford is something that ISN'T permanent? Not only that but I have to rebuy it regardless or whether or not i pass or fail the mission? (these upgrades also cost more over time - like say if you have an upgrade to start the match with 1 shotgun guy who replaces a riflemen, but you don;t buy it, the price of said powerup increases mission affter mission. Starting cost is 2800, but near the end of the campaign, these one mission use powerups costs over $40000) The second thing in he menu that you can buy costs almost twice as much as what you can afford, which is a decent upgrade. allows you to build portable healing devices. But still, no artillery units.TL;DR- Single Mission Powerups that cost more over time and can only be used once - (THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥SHOULD NOT HAPPEN IN VIDEO GAMES)- No artillery units -Mission 3 (Upgrades part 1.5):Seriously, they could have just put this in the previous mission. They introduce the first ability to destroy buildings, the "launch rocket" ability. Able to be used by any soldier. You have a certain amount of ammo (10) these rockets cost 2 ammo each. One is enough to kill a turret, and ammo can resupply over time OR you can grab ammo crates lying around. Not much I can complain about with this one. The range isn't OP, you still get hit at-least once or twice before using it. My complaint about this comes at LATER levels of the game where the rockets become almost useless, especially when enemy bases developpe certain mutations like shields. We get more one mission upgrades and one more permanent one, again, costing almost twice as much as what we currently earned, TL;DR- Introducing rocket launch -- more one mission buffs - The game goes on repeating this cycle, over and over. with little variation to units and upgrades. The difficulty however changes drastically. The aliens get stronger and stronger, their bases are more and more defended, while you get little ot not resources to compensate. At this point the game introduces "mutation" as I previously mentionned earlier. Which as I can observe, the aliens gain bonuses from what you destroy (♥♥♥♥ed right?) The more buildings and nests you destroy the STRONGER the ENEMY gets! What the♥♥♥♥♥♥kind of sense does that make?TL;DR- Mutations: You're playing good? Having a good mission? let me fix that.To bring this whiny post to a close, this game has GREAT potential. It has AMAZING potential. but somet hings need to be either reworked or changed. Simple as that. The upgrades are♥♥♥♥♥♥ you need better late game tank units.

A Screenshot of Infested Planet
By: Deltatech




Very Highly Recommended for casual playersThis is a Hidden Gem in the Steam Store. a little tower defense mixed with starcraftish upgradeable units. The graphics are good but could use an update. Sounds good as well. I have nothing bad to say about this title.I played this for three or four hours right after install!! Good gameplay, intuitive U.I. I will definitely be checking out any other titles by these Devs!!!I am Really happy that I bought this title!!!Finding games like this is always cool. content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Dynamic Strategy/Tower Defence at its finest!Strategy and Tower Defence fans will love this game. If you are a fan of either I say to you: BUY this game right now! I've purchased many games that have either failed as a Tower Defence game or a Strategy but often mixing them both has been downright rubbish... Take creeper world for example. Overly complicated for very little satisfaction. Too much emphasis on complexity which creates the difficulty rather than the challenge itself....I often steer clear of strategy games; overly complicated upgrade systems and zerg rushes...Finally a game that throws you straight into the flurry without over complicating.A game doesn't need to be extremely fancy to succeed.... It pulls off all aspects of design near perfectly.Gameplay 10/10Graphics 8/10Audio 7/10Polish 8/10Once I complete this game I look forward to Infested Planet 2.

content:
Posted: January 13
Infested Planet is a pause-and-command real time strategy game, a very dynamic and mechanically unconventional one. You start with a bunker and a team of soldiers, fending off a gazillion of buglike swarming aliens who succesively come up with accumulating dreadful capabilities emerging every once in a while. You can build further grand and minor structures to enhance your fighting force with an array of manifold remedies, hire or dismiss additional units, upgrade soldiers to weapon or function specialists, call in attack reinforcements and gain other aid as you proceed through the battleground. When needed, you pack up your stuff and move forward, regaining resources required for further expansion.You need to adapt, as enemy will also react with some impacting edges in response to your actions. The combat conditions constantly evolve. In the campaign, for each succesful mission you earn money, for which you can buy better war technology and single stage various mercenary support. The only hotkey you need to assign is the pause button, which I recommend to go spacebar with. Mind also such utilities as fire rockets, recycle and select all units. Move and attack may be useful likewise.With the Tricksters Arsenal DLC, unique abilities come to your disposal, allowing to pull off maneuvers otherwise beyond reach. The contents of Tricksters Arsenal is available for free in the Weekly Challenge mode, where different formulas of play can be found, such as survival mode, capture missions of pillar difficulty levels, as well as the ultimate challenge of Ironman. I highly recommend to start the experience with the basic version of Infested Planet. Planetary Campaign DLC introduces an entire new level of strategical management, along with a basket of significant battleground innovations.Infested Planet is a polished product, very well done. In all my lasting adventure with it, I have found only few buglike looking occurences, which have been dealt with in the manner of days directly following their report. The developer - RocketBear - is very responsive, socially open and engaged in the project, which is to be appreciated nowadays.The basic score is 8/10 wHATs grade plus one extra point for the developers attitude and the quality of presented work, which makes it 9/10 wHATs grade. Taking how rough the gameplay can get, minding it is a precise strategy coming to tactics genre, I can recommend Infested Planet to those who feel like doing this kind of digital entertainment. The STEAM price is adequate, though 12,99€ would look better.Infested Planet is fun. It is very likely to stand the test of time.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												I want to recommend this game, but at the same time I can't recommend it.Pros- RTS without mining for currency- Cost me about $5 with the DLCNegatives- Hives randomly spawning under you- You upgrade your marines and when they die, the computer will spawn a duplicate of them for themselves, yes the computer will copy your upgraded marines once they die, you had a flame thrower that died?  Now the computer has a fresh flame thrower.- Same thing goes for turrets/siege towers- Double costs of towers, you pay for the tower, and then there's the privelege of paying to use the ability of the tower.- Grind, grind, grind- If you're crazy enough to beat it, there is ZERO replay value.The difficulty ramps up on each mission the closer you get to completing it.  You destroy part of the enemy base and the enemy gets a mutation that makes the mission more difficult but it stays somewhat balanced, however at times the computer goes into cheap mode and spawns a whole lot of crap out of nowhere.On the final mission there is no such destroy mechanic.  The computer gets mutations based on time, so the first one at 10 seconds, next at 20 seconds, and so on and so forth meanwhile you are barely getting by until eventually you become overrun at which point you need to grind previous missions to get money to give youself extra resources for that final mission.All of this translates to frustration and a huge waste of time.  I loved the game, but that last mission alone turned me off so much that I have digitally "binned" this.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												It's fun until you play for a while and realize that it has one problem that is common in many indie games because it is obviously a tough thing for indie devs to program correctly: difficulty scaling. The SP campaign doesn't take long until it requires insane amounts of micromanagement that will put even Starcraft 2 to shame. It goes from being a good challenge quickly to holy fk I have to sit and redo this to beat it how many times? Until I figure out exactly what to place, where to place it, and when to place it, basically follow the devs set path they obviously had in mind and don't deviate a bit? That or lower the difficulty to easy and be made to feel like a b-tch.I mean other than that it seems like a good game. But not $15 good more like $5 good.

												Infested Planet ramps up in diffuculty way too fast , the pause button alleviates this a bit so you can think but with the endless stream of trash coming your way its easy to forget what the goal of the mission even is or worse your guys cant clean it up fast enough and gameover. Most people online from what I read gave up on the mission 'preperations' I myself barely beat it bercause the monsters go berserk and gameover in like 10 seconds if you dont have turrets up. another bad point of the game is something called mutations after you capture some enemy points the aliens (Locals) get mad and zerg you or recieve some other buff. with all their buffs on they can be unstoppable. I dont think they get any weaker as they recapture their hives either so its pretty much game over if you werent ready in advance. If it werent for these flaws I would easily recomend this game to friends. Space run is what I recomend instead of this unless its on sale than be prepared for headaches and reading forums on how to beat a mission.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I purchased this game late in the night, which may have been one of the reasons why I bought it in the first place. If you are thinking about buying this game late in the night, just wait until tomorrow morning and make your decision then. You are better off that way. --Longer reviewI had the strong craving for a new strategy game and came across Infested Planet. Initially I was skeptical of the game, primarily due to the poor graphics, however I did not want to spend more than $20 tonight, read a few of the reviews and also looked at the gameplay... and thus I bought it. The beginning of the game reminded me of some flashgames over at armorgames.com, only that I am not playing the game in the browser. I went along with and played a few of the missions, which were fairly easy until the levels substantially increased in difficulty. I don't dislike difficulty... unless that is the only thing that drives the entire game! Granted, you have some buffs and upgrades, but every mission is the same ♥♥♥♥ing thing. It's like playing skirmish, while increasing the difficulty of the AI every time you win. The story itself is rather uninteresting and after reading 2 of the messages, I just skipped through the rest of them, as they just became a nuisance.Ultimately, I would only recommend this game to those who... screw it, I don't recommend it at all. If you are into RTS and strategy games, then I rather recommend spending 25$ more to purchase a copy of Wargame.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												I've enjoyed this game but I've noticed that a single map can range from easy to impossible very quickly depending on a number of uncontrollable things. There are certain weapons and structures that make winning significantly easier and there are certain mutations that make winning almost impossible.Getting the wrong combination can turn any game into an un-winnable stalemate. I've rarely lose a game but there have been a number of games where we reach an impasse because I don't have the tools I need to win and they can't break my defenses. Maybe that speaks to my lack of skills but it does make the game a bit frustrating because I know I need to reroll the scenario and hope for a better combination.I like the game; just realize that this is a game meant to be played, not to be beaten.

Posted: March 13, 2014
												Absolutely love this game.  Did not understand the concept even after reading a couple of Reviews but after about 2 min of playing everything becomes clear.  From there you get a Mix of Strategy and Tower defense.  What is awesome is that the mutations really change up the game to the point that one strategy will not work consistently throughout the game or throughout the mission.   It is the first game where I have really found myself painted into a corner barely holding on testing multiple different strategies just to be able to push them back.  It also flips fast where you think you will have them beat and then in seconds everything crumbles and you are falling back trying to contain them.  Great game.  Hopefully they keep expanding it

It remind me of playing Enzo's Survival maps back in Warcraft 3, but deeper.Infested Planet is a fantastic strategy & tactics game, controls are similar to most RTSes but the gameplay is not.  It's all about an intense tug of war game between you and the alien bugs over control points on the map.  You and your small squad must try to control a map against thousands of times your number.The challenge is legit (infuriating at times), the fun is fairly unique, the price is very low.  Big thumbs up from me.

The enemy types are rather nicely varied, and easy to tell appart at a glance, which is glorious.  Though I do wish there was a bit more of them throwing varying enemy types mixed together. Posted: March 11, 2014
												A very interesting take on the real time strategy genre, Infested Planet eschews the building of extensive bases and farming of resources to speed up the maps into small, 5 - 10 minute frantic bursts of action. You have six marines to control and they are all the units you get. As you progress you unlock air strikes, new weapons and buffs, and defensive turrets to build. In the first couple of maps, it's very simple: Find the enemy and shoot it. Once you have some missions under your belt and the game starts to alter the rules on you, battles become chaotic, and desperate, contests of survival.There is surprising depth here, and the game has random maps to keep things interesting. There is no multiplayer option, but for a something that doesn't require a large time (or money) investment, Infested Planet serves well as a quick fix for fans of rapidly played real time strategy games.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												Several years ago I played a cool game called Attack of the Paper Zombies. It was a free strategy game I'd read about somewhere online, where you play a small band of marines tasked with wiping out alien zombie "hives" (control points), but with each additional point taken, the hives mutate various (random) abilities that increase the challenge of further progress. Apparently, this game was popular enough that the developer decided to quit his day job and focus on further developing and polishing his game for commercial release. Infested Planet is that game.I won't go to in depth about the game itself (special thanks to filly73 for seeing it on my Steam wishlist and gifting it to me), and while I didn't really notice that much "different" about the new game (other then the changed art style, better graphics, background story, and such), when I went back and played the original again, I realized that a very significant change had been made, that significantly increase what I found the most enjoyable about Infested Planet—basically, the removal of any penalty for changing your strategy…Basically, every time you capture an additional control points, you gain additional "research points" with which to either increase the number of "mercenaries" you control, upgrade those mercenaries with a variety of weapons, or build offensive/defensive structures such as automated gun turrets, or unlock various effects to support your control point–capturing efforts. While many of these features are nearly unchanged from the original Attack of the Paper Zombies, the significant change is that in Infested Planet, there is no cost to "recycling" any of these upgrades. Spent 4 Research Points on a gun turret, or on a flame thrower for one of you mercenaries? Recycle it, and get back all 4 points to put towards some other upgrade, whereas in the original game, you'd only get back 2 points. In my opinion, this change not only made the game more "fun" (you can experiment with different strategies without incurring any penalty), but also allowed opened up the option for employing strategies that DEPENDED on repeatedly changing your arsenal, something that would have resulted in attrition in the original.TL;DR: A fun strategy game that allows a great deal of variety in how its challenges may be approached.
