Posted: March 14, 2014
												Tight, focused, exciting gameplay.Graphics are crisp and bright and tell you exactly what's going on, while being full of style.  Menus, character portraits, and icons are all expertly made.Perfect UI.  You can zoom as far as you want.  Everything has a shortcut, they're visible in-game, and they're on the left of the keyboard.  You receive appropriate alerts, and the range and orders of every unit can be seen.  Everything about the UI says "oh, they thought of that too".Mutations and upgrades keep things fresh.  Try random missions or continue with the story.  There's a "daily challenge" I haven't tried yet.  There doesn't appear to be an "easy" or optimal strategy.  Use what works in different situations.  Use the generous money you get from missions to buy new technology.  This game is excited to get the goodies in your hands.The gameplay is fluid.  You might be losing, badly; that doesn't mean you can't regroup and win.  Everything can be redone in the middle of a mission and early mistakes can be recovered from.  It's hard as hell and it can be frustrating.  But persevere and you'll break through.Very impressed with this game.  Paid $15 and have been absolutely delighted.

Posted: February 2, 2016
												My score: 9/10An enjoyable RTS. It's kind of like playing Starcraft against the zerg. I appreciate that there are different strategies that you can play, and there is no one set way of playing the game "right." The AI mutates, which means you have to change your strategy on the fly, and you are able to do so because you can change character class, and buildings on the spot. The game is fast-paced, and there's no resource collecting.Some problems with the game though is that it can be rubber-bandy. You take over one spot and another one gets taken over. You retake it, and the enemy regroups somewhere else... Another problem is that the 'tidying up' phase can be a bit drawn out. Not so bad that you're looking for one peasant hiding somewhere in the fog of war, but there's a point when you can say: "I won already, c'mon..."Pros:Various strategies work equally well.Fast-paced.Good variety of buildings and character classes.Feels good gunning down waves of aliens.No grinding or other time-consuming activities.Cons:The game is a bit short. But it has decent replay value.Graphics could be better.Controls are not as precise, or snappy as I would've liked.Excellent game, worthy of it's price tag, and an even better deal if on sale.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												First impressions:  I recommend this game to die hard RTS buffs looking for something different.  I wouldn't call it a tower defense game though.  Although you do place some turrets at times, the game is more mobile and you keep moving from area to area clearing out bug infested buildings which you take over slowly turning them into bases to win the game.  At some point in the game after purchasing the buff, you can heal at each base.  You do not go inside buildings, just around them.  They all look the same and server one purpose.  To become another healing point for you once cleared.  You must clear every building to beat the map.This is like other reviewers have pointed out.  It is a very basic, repetitious swarm control game.  You are constantly controlling areas and trying to destroy the spawn points around the small maps as fast as you can.  As I said, the game is pretty basic and get repetitious fast.  One reason for this is that you will play the same maps over and over again to get money to purchase perks.  Some perks are permanent and some are one time use.  It is somewhat a grind-fest!The maps are different.  One reviewer stated it was the same map the whole game and that is not true.   They just look the same as the textures are not all that different.  At one point I found it harder to pass the same level than before and it was pure strategy.  I had lost my 3 shotgunners….  If you lose the soldiers that got the good weapon drops, they respawn with basic weapons again and makes it hard to pass beat the maps sometimes.  Don't lose them!  Heal them!This is just my first impressions and I might change or update this review, but as I said, the game is fairly basic and gets repetitious, but does have that Starship Troopers feel of being overwhelmed by aliens!  The game seems solid, polished and made with love of the genre.  So far I recommend it to RTS die hards only!

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Great game. The missions are quite easy in the beginning, but they get challenging soon enough.What I like:- Excellent mix of big strategy and small-scale tactics.- In most other RTS, there is a tipping point where you know the AI won't recover, so the rest of the mission (often a big part) is just clean-up duty. In this game, however, the aliens get stronger and more vicious the more you advance, so it stays interesting until the end.- You get a full refund for salvaged *and* destroyed buildings, so you can experiment and adapt during a mission. (Think "control/supply points", not "money".)- *Lots* of alien carnage - alien kill counts in a mission are typically >10.000 :)- Great music + sound effects- Overall, a very well thought-out game and UIBefore buying, I was a bit sceptical whether I'd like the visuals, but they actualy work out quite well in-game.The only downside is that there are only few actual campaign missions - 16, I think, including some very easy ones. But there are various random missions (at different levels) and weekly challenges that are a lot of fun on their own, so there's enough play time as it is.

Posted: August 15, 2015
												Incredibly addicting with a great learning curve, this indie game presents a challenging, although fair, experience for any RTS fan. Instantly one of my favorite games ever. By commanding a squad of variable size throughout random missions (although there is a story mode, and it is quite fun), the player is tasked with taking control of command points from a never-ending swarm of aliens. If you like Starship Troopers, you'll love this game. It has a few nods here and there and somewhat matches the feel of the film(s). I never noticed any bugs (outside of the endless swarm that you'll find your space marines constantly firing at) so it is a well-programmed affair. My only real complaints reside with the marines themselves, I do wish that they had proper voice-acting and dialogue. Like the marines of the earlier Halo video games, I think it would really spice up the experience. If there is ever a sequel, I'm certainly buying it. It'd be neat to see a CO-OP mode where each player commands squads, but it isn't terribly necessary. All in all, it's a fantastic experience that kept me enthralled to the point of forgetting to sleep. On a side note, I purchased this at about the same time as I purchased Dawn of War 2, which is another RTS. I can honestly tell you with complete certainty that I like this game more.

Posted: August 30, 2015
												Bought this largely because of the great reviews, and yes, it is that good. It's just the right balance of difficulty, where you don't feel overwhelmed but you will lose sometimes. And the thing about it is, the gameplay changes so much on the fly. A mutation of the enemy creatures will change the dynamic of the level, or suddenly they start sending a huge attack towards a lightly defended area. You also have a certain amount of 'credits', don't remember the actual term they use in game, that allow you to buy soldiers or powerups on each level. Because you can cash in units for a full refund at any time, that means that you also can change strategies mid-level when you see that a plan isn't working like you'd hoped. That is, you can sell cheap soldiers and equip your existing ones better, buy turrets with the extra money, or any other variety of different approaches.There are a lot of indie games on here with great concepts that suck because they have terrible execution. This game is the opposite - a concept that doesn't sound like much, but it's executed perfectly. I don't even usually like these types of games but Infested Planet is an exception. Outstanding game - if you're curious enough about the game to read this review, then trust me, it is worth buying.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												I didn't really expect much from this game, bought it in a sale, it seemed kinda interesting, then I forgot about it.Found it in my library recently, decided to give it a shot, got addicted to it! It's the kind of game that I wanted to play for a long time but everyone would always over complicate things or it would be a glitchy mess.No glitches found so far, you tell a unit to build, walk and attack, walk, or carry something. Every unit can do this, groups are surprisingly easy to work with and everything is nice and basic. There's no money, you have points that you can spend on buildings or troups that can be refunded, you can't lose these points, but you can gain points depending on the mission. Story mode was a joy to go through with interesting situations, the escort missions were done right (They draw a path and tell you when they plan to start moving, just clear it out and secure the bases around it, done!) Basic but interesting situations with adapting hives that change constantly to keep them interesting (Counter attack mutation always made things slightly awkward when capturing a new base, slow down poison made my army of flamethrowers struggle to get to the fight etc). It's a simple game, but it doesn't need to be any more then that. Really enjoyed it- looking forward to the developers next game!

Posted: June 20, 2015
												I'm actually not quite sure why I enjoy this game so much. It's like the Starcraft missions where you lead a few marines into swarms of melee-only zerglings, and the marines mow them down right & left while trying not to get overwhelmed.Likes:-- No diddling with resource harvesting: There are some resource & ammo crates, but otherwise resources come from capturing the enemy bases.-- Death is temporary: If a marine dies, they get resurrected after a delay.-- 100% refund on recycled buildings: Recycling one turret and adding a new one closer to the front has a net cost of zero.-- Small numbers on resources: 12 resources means one fixed turret and a soldier upgraded to shotgun. Once you get a few more resources, do you recycle that shotgun to build another fixed turret?This combination means you're constantly considering what the current situation needs and where to apply your limited resources. Which is nice.Dislikes:Really my main dislike is that unit subtleties aren't clear: it badly needs a unit encyclopedia. Is a normal marine effective against one of those bigger beetles with spiky armor? No--this is a useful fact to know, but the game doesn't make this obvious. There's a science/exploration theme to the campaign, so an in-game encyclopedia would fit. The tougher missions would be more palatable if I could regroup and figure out where I went wrong...but without knowing unit strengths & weaknesses it's tougher to figure out.Overall: worthwhile, totally worth the sale buy.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Great game. The missions are quite easy in the beginning, but they get challenging soon enough.What I like:- Excellent mix of big strategy and small-scale tactics.- In most other RTS, there is a tipping point where you know the AI won't recover, so the rest of the mission (often a big part) is just clean-up duty. In this game, however, the aliens get stronger and more vicious the more you advance, so it stays interesting until the end.- You get a full refund for salvaged *and* destroyed buildings, so you can experiment and adapt during a mission. (Think "control/supply points", not "money".)- *Lots* of alien carnage - alien kill counts in a mission are typically >10.000 :)- Great music + sound effects- Overall, a very well thought-out game and UIBefore buying, I was a bit sceptical whether I'd like the visuals, but they actualy work out quite well in-game.The only downside is that there are only few actual campaign missions - 16, I think, including some very easy ones. But there are various random missions (at different levels) and weekly challenges that are a lot of fun on their own, so there's enough play time as it is.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												Really enjoyed this one. A fairly simple strategy with a lot more depth than meets-the-eye. While it does play like your standard RTS, you have a unique resource that once you have it, you can use it indefinetly. For example-- you can make your troops fast moving scouts, for 5 points and have 2 left over to change them again, into flame-troops. Then swap back. The resource never really "burns away" like in your standard RTS, it just takes new shape. So as your enemy uses new "mutations" (their version of research or tech) you can totally revamp your strategy on the fly.That makes the game a little out of the box. It's not revolutionary, but for the $4 I paid, it was well worth it.Only played through the story, that feels like maybe 1/3 of the whole game. 10/10 would type an over used "10/10-ign" meme again! Posted: October 6, 2015
												How would I describe Infested Planet? Well it is basically the Starship Troopers films and animation in a nutshell. Your objective varies for each level; either being destroy all alien hives, survive, or escort. You, the player/commander, are given points (BP, the purple currency) at the start of each level and gain more for destroying hives, recyling buildings and units, and capturing boxs. The tools vary from support buildings or automated turrets. Your opponents, the alien scum, is well pretty dang mindless. They attack you on a path and can be stopped with ease. The basic ones anyway. They do adapt just so you know, I'll let you find out.Pros: Commiting genocide on alien scumOrdering your men to their immediate doom(But no in all seriousness)Good unit pathfinding <--- A+ (Is a must game developers, do not ignore this!)Unit variiety <--- units can be upgraded with different weapons and behave differently depending on weaponStrong replayabilityCompetent enemy AI <---- may not appear it but they are. Beware of certain mutation combinations.Cons:Lack of multiplayer.

												Like everyone else says, this is a fantastic game. Doesn't look like much, but it's great. Tons of fun. Vaguely reminiscent of Starcraft, but without the base building. Rewards tenacity and good tactics. Think that bug infestation is impossible to kill? Quit being soft, soldier!

Posted: January 1, 2016
												This game is unique and familiar at the same time. It feels like a warcraft 3 map with only heroes. You have a team of 3-9 soldiers that will go against thousands of  enemies, literally. The enemies are simple melee at first but develop much deadlier abilities later in the game or even later on the same map. To counter this your team can change skills on the fly to adapt to any situation. Because of this the game now oddly feels like a first person shooter where you can change from invisibile assassin to close quarters shotgunner to sniper rifle and then to flamethrower in just 3 seconds leaving behind assassinated enemy heroes, dozens of dead spitting aliens a destroyed tower and a burning building including the enemies in it. There is no limit to the changes you can make, marines can change an unlimited number of times, buildings can be recycled getting the full resources back, research and upgrades can be sold back as well. The only limitation is that except plain marines everything else uses resources and thus the number of upgrades that you can have at the same time is limited. Thus it is very important to determine which upgrades you need at a certain point in time and establish a strategy before you jump into combat. The game also features a pause button which I rarely use as i prefer real time strategy over turn based mechanics.You gain resources for captuing enemy points and dragging resource crates back to the bases you own. You do not lose resources when losing a point so while the progress may be slow and incremental, you definetly can try new approaches if you get pushed back after a point capture.There is definetly replay values with random generated maps and a ladder system that shows how well you did on a map as compared to other players. There is also a weekly challenge and a nice story mode with additional mechanics.I definetly recommend the game.

Posted: March 14, 2014
What to pay : <10€.You play a mercenary commander aiding the army colonisation of a new planet. Unfortuantely, it has a bug problem.Infested Planet adds what most tower defences lack; actual strategy. Surprisingly well balanced, this game isn't going to punish you, but it's not going sit down and take it either. The 10 to 15 min missions and forgiving nature make this a very agreeable "I only have a little while" title.  You can even surrender a mission at any point and still walk away with a little of your merc pay. Some of the missions don't even need you to progress to make cash. It's a case of not dying.So what do you spend your merc pay on? Well, for a start, upgrades. The odd thing about them is that while many games do the same, the offerings here really give flexibility. It doesn't truely matter WHAT you unlock, but rather what you build on map. Even if you buy an upgrade you didn't want, no worries. You can't undo it, but you're not cockblocked.You can also purchase one-shot additional mercenaries. You'll never run out of things to spend cash on, nor missions :)My best tip : minefields are often a better choice than a turret if you can use it in a chokepoint.

Posted: April 27, 2015
												Solid core concept, and with the recently launched DLC, it's more of the same thing, but in a very good way! The basic premise of Infested Planet is that you have just a small group of elite soldiers to battle through an endless swarm of aliens to destroy their hives and gain victory.The DLC (Trickster's Arsenal) gives you additional battlefield maneuverability (teleport your troops anywhere, call down temporary solider backups, etc) which gives a greater number of tactical options to utilise your ammo resource. At the same time, the aliens also get some new toys such as the hive runner which attempts to re-establish the hive elsewhere after you've destroyed a hive.The gameplay can feel slow if you are playing in the easier levels. To truly enjoy the intensity and the game's value, you need to bring on the pain and go Ironman Mode and play at the highest difficulties.The weekly skirmishes offer randomised maps and a scoreboard to see how well you are doing against other players, which provides great replayability value.I purchased Infested Planet a while back, but immediately purchased the DLC when it came out. I sincerely recommend this to anyone who enjoys tactical decision-making at your own pace.My only (minor) grimace is the lack of map objectives apart from destroying the hives. In the campaign, one map that stood out for me was the one where you had to bring back canisters to your base while trying to fend of the infested assassins. Adding randomised additional map objectives such as these would significantly amp up the intensity, replayability and thoughtfulness required on the player's part, which I'm sure hardcore Infested Planet players such as myself would immensely enjoy.9/10 - a solid piece of work!

Posted: May 8, 2015
												I highly recommend this game. There is a short, generic story by means of dialogue windows to go along with it that serves its purpose to move from one mission to the next. The reason this game is great though is because of the gameplay. I feel that the player and the enemy are very well matched and the mechanic for capturing points with your squad (or other mission objectives) to build up your squad is rewarding. In addition, I found that the Attack+Move command works intelligently (e.g. snipers/scouts will target towers/buildings among the horde of enemies so there is no need to micromanage when things get crazy). The variety of weapons/technologies and enemy types is more than enough to keep the game interesting and allow for multiple strategies. In the Campaign section there are multiple types of games too (standard, raid, hunt, etc.) that will shift your strategies.I am most impressed with the Endgame content. I felt the acheivements were adequately challenging yet fair. In addition to the Campaign, there is a Skirmish mode and a set of Weekly challenges (with a leaderboard). The Skirmish mode is basically a map generator with all sorts of customization. The only thing I would ask for from the Skirmish mode is the ability to increase the rate of growth of the enemy past the current capping point. Otherwise, for the asking price, this is a great game.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Infested Planet is brilliantly asymmetrical. On one side, the marines. Rarely more than a dozen, armed with rifles, shotguns, or other weapons, marines run fast and hit hard. On the other side, the swarm. Hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands of aliens, slowly creeping towards the player’s bunkers. Mutations in the aliens constantly alter and improve the abilities of the swarm, and force the player to re-evaluate strategies. The player needs to simultaneously balance holding off the enemy swarm and taking the fight back to the aliens. The result is a complicated and tense game of thrusts into weak flanks, retreats from overwhelming force, desperate stands at choke points, and constant shifting of troop load out and strategy to match enemy capabilities. Highly recommended.

												Small game by indie developer , its nice to see the developer keeps interest and is loyal to thier fans by adding new weekly missions . The graphics are simple but very clear and effective , the gameplay is what truly shines . Its a mix of tower defence and rts , you are defending lanes and your bases while taking over alien nests . Random things can happen mid mission such as aliens evolving or more nests popping up . Keeps you on your toes and is challanging but not impossible . I dont rate too many games , im a fussy gamer and it takes a lot for a game to win me over ... this game has won me over and so far im really enjoying it . After i finish the campaign i look forward to trying the weekly missions the devs supply .

Posted: June 27, 2015
												I didn't really expect much from this game, bought it in a sale, it seemed kinda interesting, then I forgot about it.Found it in my library recently, decided to give it a shot, got addicted to it! It's the kind of game that I wanted to play for a long time but everyone would always over complicate things or it would be a glitchy mess.No glitches found so far, you tell a unit to build, walk and attack, walk, or carry something. Every unit can do this, groups are surprisingly easy to work with and everything is nice and basic. There's no money, you have points that you can spend on buildings or troups that can be refunded, you can't lose these points, but you can gain points depending on the mission. Story mode was a joy to go through with interesting situations, the escort missions were done right (They draw a path and tell you when they plan to start moving, just clear it out and secure the bases around it, done!) Basic but interesting situations with adapting hives that change constantly to keep them interesting (Counter attack mutation always made things slightly awkward when capturing a new base, slow down poison made my army of flamethrowers struggle to get to the fight etc). It's a simple game, but it doesn't need to be any more then that. Really enjoyed it- looking forward to the developers next game!

Posted: April 18, 2015
												Infested planet is a nice twist to the RTS genre. This time around you get small squad of tough guys and need to fight thousands of insecoid aliens. The closest thing I can compare it to would be perhaps Terran vs Zerg in Starcraft, but taken to extreme. The game mechanics are very well designed, missions are tough, especially later in the campaign, when aliens play all the tricks in their arsenal and you reallly need to adapt your strategy as the situations changes.  On the other hand you can make your life easier by playing some optional missions to earn cash. You can do it as many times as you want and then spend the cash on bonuses that will help you beat the campaign. An extra flamethrower or even additional rifle marine can be priceless. What is great about the game's design is that it allows you to recycle the resources you spent. This means you can try different things and if you make a mistake or circumstances changes in a way you couldn't possibly expect, you can still correct it. Well, you can at least try :-). This is an indie game, done by a small team, so don't expect fancy graphics. What you'll see is clean & readable. For me that's perfectly fine. The only real problem I have with this game is that it crashes to desktop on my Mac  from time to time. It doesn't make the game unplayable, but it's annoying.If you like RTS-like games you should try Infested Planet.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												Infested Planet is a great singleplayer RTS where you control a handful of mercenaries and their toys to defeat thousands millions of aliens. Because of the big contrast in numbers from both sides, you have to outsmart the AI, use chokepoints and carefully plan out your route to conquest. This makes it a challenging game, which makes it very rewarding when clearing a level.A great feature in Infested Planet is that you earn points from capturing enemy Hives, which you can spend on more toys for your guys. The best part is that you can redistribute your points at any time: this means that if a tactic is not working, you can fall back, reclaim everything, redistribute your points and try again.The game has a 30 level campaign (17 story missions and 13 random missions); 5 weekly challenges at different difficulties, where you can compete with other people to get the fastest time; and a random map generator where you can change almost anything: from the number of Hives, the powerups (mutations) the enemy has, how much resources your team has, the difficulty and many more. This means you have endless fun despite being a singleplayer.

Posted: March 14, 2014
What to pay : <10€.You play a mercenary commander aiding the army colonisation of a new planet. Unfortuantely, it has a bug problem.Infested Planet adds what most tower defences lack; actual strategy. Surprisingly well balanced, this game isn't going to punish you, but it's not going sit down and take it either. The 10 to 15 min missions and forgiving nature make this a very agreeable "I only have a little while" title.  You can even surrender a mission at any point and still walk away with a little of your merc pay. Some of the missions don't even need you to progress to make cash. It's a case of not dying.So what do you spend your merc pay on? Well, for a start, upgrades. The odd thing about them is that while many games do the same, the offerings here really give flexibility. It doesn't truely matter WHAT you unlock, but rather what you build on map. Even if you buy an upgrade you didn't want, no worries. You can't undo it, but you're not cockblocked.You can also purchase one-shot additional mercenaries. You'll never run out of things to spend cash on, nor missions :)My best tip : minefields are often a better choice than a turret if you can use it in a chokepoint.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												"The only good bug, is a DEAD bug!"-Displaced resident of Buenos AiresIn a game that asks if you apes want to live forever, all you can do is arm up and take it to the enemy. For such a small game, Infested Planet offers quite a bit of entertainment. It can be play in nice little 30-40 minute increments, or for longer stretches...depending on how many bugs you need to kill.It's well balanced, each map having a variety of different methods to victory. There is certainly no "right" build order, and the player is free to fight the way that they perfer. Additionally, the mutation mechanic ensures that you never quite get too comfortable.All in all, it's a good bit of fun.

You see so many easy tower defense games but this is so easy level 1-5 but later your going to have a pain with this but totally worth time spending and coming up with a good plan.Genre: Tower Defense and Strategy.When to buy: Well a sale is great but 15$ for this game is honestly worth it completely :)Now for a personal review: First I wanted to say that this game is very good but i still have yet to beat everything cause it is quite hard.  There are trading cards and achievments for those certain people and the achievments are easy to get for the most part though. But back to the game itself you look at this and it look slike an FPS but then you actual play the game and your like woah wait what am I playing. So you have a squad of 4 men who are able to be upgraded into differnt classes and you are able to build stations to improve your bases quality. So your goal is to take your squad and invade aliens bases. Over time the aliens gain perks which are very annoying for the most part which makes this part of the game the planning part. For most story missions there are set levels where you have to play on but there are also side quests where every time you do it the level is randomly generated which is also another plus. So you take over bases build turrets and you have this thing called BP which is pretty much how you upgrade things and your squad of 4 may be increased using BP. You may also redo any missions to gain more money for perks. Some perks last forever and some are a one time mission only. Now for the two side quests you may do. There are two types the first type is command and conquer and the second part is time limit destruction. In command and conquer you must pretty much take over evrey base you see, you have infinite time but let me warn you as they will gain perks the longer you play. There are 3 majoy difficulties which are where the achievments come in. Now for time limit destruction you must destroy all of the bases within a time limit. For every base you destroy you gain more time. This also has 3 majoy difficulties just like command and conquer. So overall this game is worth getting for anybody you can grasp the concept easily you might rage later on but you won't regret this buy :)!!!!!!!!

Posted: June 27, 2015
												I didn't really expect much from this game, bought it in a sale, it seemed kinda interesting, then I forgot about it.Found it in my library recently, decided to give it a shot, got addicted to it! It's the kind of game that I wanted to play for a long time but everyone would always over complicate things or it would be a glitchy mess.No glitches found so far, you tell a unit to build, walk and attack, walk, or carry something. Every unit can do this, groups are surprisingly easy to work with and everything is nice and basic. There's no money, you have points that you can spend on buildings or troups that can be refunded, you can't lose these points, but you can gain points depending on the mission. Story mode was a joy to go through with interesting situations, the escort missions were done right (They draw a path and tell you when they plan to start moving, just clear it out and secure the bases around it, done!) Basic but interesting situations with adapting hives that change constantly to keep them interesting (Counter attack mutation always made things slightly awkward when capturing a new base, slow down poison made my army of flamethrowers struggle to get to the fight etc). It's a simple game, but it doesn't need to be any more then that. Really enjoyed it- looking forward to the developers next game!

Posted: June 26, 2015
												WIthin my relatively short time playing I have found myself seriously enjoying this title. Though the visuals aren't exactly top-notch, the gameplay itself is quite visceral. The way you destroy huge groups of endless alien creatures is well done. Using the equipment you develop feels like it is actually useful and trying to use what resources you have effectively is challenging but far from impossible. The difficulty both from scenario to scenario as well as within each piece is reasonably well-done. If I was to criticise this game for anything it would be that there isn't the ability to hotkey squads like in a standard RTS so you have to be a bit more careful about splitting your troops up, but most of the time you bundle up and attack move anyway. This leads to a bit of potential oversimplicity for some, although I like the straightforward nature of the game.Overall an enjoyable experience and well worth it having picked it up while it was on sale.

												This was a lot of fun for a few hours. I got stuck eventually, but that's probably not the game's fault.I love the degree of abstraction in the design. The relentless top down view is so much more useful than the usual isometric 3D mapped design used frequently elsewhere.The pause/command/run mechanic was perfectly thought out, with units responding intelligently to commands.I could have used a little bit more tutorial. Posted: March 14, 2014
What to pay : <10€.You play a mercenary commander aiding the army colonisation of a new planet. Unfortuantely, it has a bug problem.Infested Planet adds what most tower defences lack; actual strategy. Surprisingly well balanced, this game isn't going to punish you, but it's not going sit down and take it either. The 10 to 15 min missions and forgiving nature make this a very agreeable "I only have a little while" title.  You can even surrender a mission at any point and still walk away with a little of your merc pay. Some of the missions don't even need you to progress to make cash. It's a case of not dying.So what do you spend your merc pay on? Well, for a start, upgrades. The odd thing about them is that while many games do the same, the offerings here really give flexibility. It doesn't truely matter WHAT you unlock, but rather what you build on map. Even if you buy an upgrade you didn't want, no worries. You can't undo it, but you're not cockblocked.You can also purchase one-shot additional mercenaries. You'll never run out of things to spend cash on, nor missions :)My best tip : minefields are often a better choice than a turret if you can use it in a chokepoint.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												The moment I saw the trailer for this, I knew I'd like it. Here's why I do:1. The size of the experience. It's a properly bite-sized game: you put in ten to twenty minutes (granted, at the early-middle part of the game where I am) and get out solid strategy.2. Upgrades and buybacks. The game doesn't penalize you for trying something new, discovering it doesn't work, and selling the weapons and structures you made in pursuit of a certain tactic.3. The overall feel. Surmounting insurmountable odds always feels great, and wading slowly forward into a morass of smoking insectoid ichor is a good way to induce that feeling.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												How would I describe Infested Planet? Well it is basically the Starship Troopers films and animation in a nutshell. Your objective varies for each level; either being destroy all alien hives, survive, or escort. You, the player/commander, are given points (BP, the purple currency) at the start of each level and gain more for destroying hives, recyling buildings and units, and capturing boxs. The tools vary from support buildings or automated turrets. Your opponents, the alien scum, is well pretty dang mindless. They attack you on a path and can be stopped with ease. The basic ones anyway. They do adapt just so you know, I'll let you find out.Pros: Commiting genocide on alien scumOrdering your men to their immediate doom(But no in all seriousness)Good unit pathfinding <--- A+ (Is a must game developers, do not ignore this!)Unit variiety <--- units can be upgraded with different weapons and behave differently depending on weaponStrong replayabilityCompetent enemy AI <---- may not appear it but they are. Beware of certain mutation combinations.Cons:Lack of multiplayer.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												In a word: fun.if you like RTS games, then this is a fun, casual horde-mode RTS. There's not a great deal of base building, just strategic turret placement, and you don't really build an army so much as micro-manage a small squad.very satisfying watching all those little bugs die, but there's actually so many of them that if you're not careful you will be overwhelmed. they have more powerful units and defenses which you'll need to take into consideration, so it's by no means too easy, after the first few levels the difficulty ramps up reasonably fast, and as you go through the story you'll unlock more side-missions which are repeatable and randomly generated.9/10, not absolute perfection, but then what is?

Posted: August 12, 2015
												Okay, this game is pretty fantastic.Infested Planet is similar to World in Conflict (or an older game Ground Control) in sense that you take control of a small squad and have a limited way of expanding or upgrading it, resulting in a game where winning mostly comes down to how well you can manage your units.And, oh boy, how much fun that is.Each mission starts with a certain amount of points, that you can spend on upgrading your marines to different classes, building supporting structures, or calling in for additional units. Because there is no way to lose those points, you are free to mess around and experiment with them as much as you like. At any point in the mission you can reclaim your invested resources and instantly spend them on something else. Which, as the game progress, will actually become an essential tactic in your path to victory.At first you will be having fun by simply killing the aliens the hundreds, but as you become better at the game so does the aliens start evolving. Sooner or later they will start countering your favorite tactics by dynamically developing new forms of attack, which is exactly why it becomes so important to be comfortable with reusing your resources and reforming your squad to use a different set of units.Although the game starts rather easy, it ramps up in challenge quite nicely, and by the end reaching a point where you will be forced to use every possible weapon in your arsenal. Infested Planet is easy to get into, offers quick action, fast missions, and most importantly tones of fun.8/10

												An excelent game for someone who enjoys strategy games. The last 9 hours have been a blast. The controls were very intuitive and the interface easy to interact with. The second to last mission boggled me a bit but only because the boss has a bizzare amount of health and no indicator bar. The resource system is awesome with the abilty to upgrade your squad going into the missions by using the money earned in the last one being a fantastic idea. The need to balance your force between infantry and defenses is a great mechanic, being able to sell back the extra infantry dynamically when a more static defence is needed or hire more on the spot when you need to run to a defense makes the game playable in many different ways. If you are going to play then remember that  you can instantly sell any unit for a full refund of it's price. Also if you suddenly have a lot of money, it is probably because your defenses just got steamrolled. This game is definitely recommended

Posted: April 1, 2016
												I bought this game during the recent sale. Overall I am happy with my purchase. That being said lets begin with the review.This is a very strategic game where even slight mistakes equals instant failure. You play as marine mercenaries fighting a war against a alien bug spiecies. In the campaign you acquire money from playing missions even failing them. You can then use this money to unlock upgrades to marines, structures, and abilities which you can then use in game.Overtime in the games, with moderately challenging difficulty, the aliens tend to mutate to the point they just steam roll right over your heavily deffended base. This being said if played correctly you can as the marines do the same to the aliens.I bought the DLC as part of the sale so some of the following may regard to it. The in game set up is very well done with well planned hotkeys it is very easy to manage upgrades are abilities quickly. Although you can beat the campaign and most of the random missions in under 8 to 10 hours the actual campaign missions are very replayable. If that is not enough for you there is also the ability to play skirmishes where you choose the map and difficulty. In addition you can also change the skirmish settings giving you pratically infinite resources for a easy fun game where you can screw around,All this being said it is still a strategy game. So if you don't like losing over and over to what seems to be an unwinable struggle against the alien bug race then this may not be the game for you. However if you like a challenge and strategy games I highly recomend this game. Thanks for your time!

Posted: January 24, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Real time strategy "Tower Defence" game.Interface/Menu/SettingsYou can play in fullscreen or windowed mode.There are many different resolution sizes.There is a music volume slidebar available.There is a sound volume slidebar available.Able to change the controls on your keyboard.You are able to disable the screen shake.Has skirmish mode, Story mode and DLC Campaign.About the game.You will play with a set of marines to take over the enemy hives and elimating them one by one. There are literally SWARMS of enemies which will constantly attack you and you have to hold them off or engage them to stop the alien swarm coming out of the hives. You are able to upgrade your marines with better weapons, making defensive or offensive buildings or support upgrades. Hives will get stronger and they will gain upgrades and buffs whenever they are getting closer and closer to defeat. Aliens may change their attack pattern way and attack you from a different angle. Enemies could get like shields, Regeneration, stronger Aliens and alot more. This is randomized. Marines that dies while they are equipped with a different weapons, will not make them drop their weapon. The respawn timer depends on the equipped weapon marine.Interesting story and has side missions.Random maps and Enemy Buffs.Defensive/offensive/support buildings. Upgradeable marines with different weapons during ingame.Could be repetitive but also addictive.Upgradable/unlockable perks and buffs, Permanently and during ingame.Interesting gameplay,Decent music.Easy controls.Other things.Aliens will choose+Find an alternate path to attack and surprise you. Which will mean you have to keep your eyes and stay focused on all times. You will never know if you get attacked from the back or a totally unexpected way. I like this idea and makes the alien more "random" and forces you to stay tuned. If you aren't doing this then the enemy could make a comeback and you will lose the game.-------------------I Give this game a 8/10

Posted: September 26, 2014
												First impressions:  I recommend this game to die hard RTS buffs looking for something different.  I wouldn't call it a tower defense game though.  Although you do place some turrets at times, the game is more mobile and you keep moving from area to area clearing out bug infested buildings which you take over slowly turning them into bases to win the game.  At some point in the game after purchasing the buff, you can heal at each base.  You do not go inside buildings, just around them.  They all look the same and server one purpose.  To become another healing point for you once cleared.  You must clear every building to beat the map.This is like other reviewers have pointed out.  It is a very basic, repetitious swarm control game.  You are constantly controlling areas and trying to destroy the spawn points around the small maps as fast as you can.  As I said, the game is pretty basic and get repetitious fast.  One reason for this is that you will play the same maps over and over again to get money to purchase perks.  Some perks are permanent and some are one time use.  It is somewhat a grind-fest!The maps are different.  One reviewer stated it was the same map the whole game and that is not true.   They just look the same as the textures are not all that different.  At one point I found it harder to pass the same level than before and it was pure strategy.  I had lost my 3 shotgunners….  If you lose the soldiers that got the good weapon drops, they respawn with basic weapons again and makes it hard to pass beat the maps sometimes.  Don't lose them!  Heal them!This is just my first impressions and I might change or update this review, but as I said, the game is fairly basic and gets repetitious, but does have that Starship Troopers feel of being overwhelmed by aliens!  The game seems solid, polished and made with love of the genre.  So far I recommend it to RTS die hards only!

Posted: May 19, 2015

Posted: May 24, 2015
												Infested Planet is a real-time strategy game with a tug-of-war play style & take-and-hold objectives.  Science fiction themed, the game takes place on a new planet that is being colonized by space fairing humans who encounter another sentient form of life on the planet.The Good: This was the best example of an indie RTS I've ever seen!  It is almost impossible to compete the complexity (and the limitless budget) of games like StarCraft or Company of Heroes but this little indie title did an excellent job of giving us a simplified and streamlined RTS that didn’t "simplify" the fun out of playing the game.  There a light research tree, single mission unlocks for the extra tough missions, a weekly challenge for those who want more and just enough story and music to be fun but not get in the way.  The units seemed balanced and everything you unlock (almost) has a purpose and is useful in the right situation.  The game is also delightfully challenging; it’s by no means a push over but you’ll lose a few mission before ya get it right!The Bad:  At least for me, the chopper air-strike and the ammo facility combo seemed really (Really!) good, that may need a small nerf but really you have to use it at an opportune time or the bugs just swarm back over the area.  Also, and this is always a sideways compliment, the game was a bit too short.  I beat it and all of the (non-weekly) side skirmishes in ~14 hours but hey, there's always endless/challenge mode if ya want more.The Funny:  Nothing really ... all action and fun, no bugs, nothing crashed.  I was too busy kicking♥♥♥♥♥to laugh!Summary: 9 out of 10, this is everything an indie game should be.  It didn't try to say, "We're better than AAA titles," (nor did it price itself as such).  It just brought a fun, action packed arena in a familiar but still unique package.  At the time of this writing the game is ~4 bucks and since most movies cost ya $18ish for 1.5 - 2 hours of entertainment I'd take a game like this over any movie night.  This game is great and I'll definitely buy from this group if they put out more stuff.  The game is Infested Planet: Get it, Play it, Love it!

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Gear up Marine!  Time to lock & load and wash those bug guts off your boots.Infested Planet is a pleasure to play.  Nothing like hordes of bugs charging your position while you do everything you can to keep alive.  The game does ramp up quickly but nothing you can't handle.  Endgame requires buying items from the store inbetween missions.  I could see not having anything but the powerups and troop classes are critical.  Once you have played through, the weekly chalanges will keep the game fresh for awhile.  Horde mode for the GLORY!!!

Posted: June 27, 2015
												I didn't really expect much from this game, bought it in a sale, it seemed kinda interesting, then I forgot about it.Found it in my library recently, decided to give it a shot, got addicted to it! It's the kind of game that I wanted to play for a long time but everyone would always over complicate things or it would be a glitchy mess.No glitches found so far, you tell a unit to build, walk and attack, walk, or carry something. Every unit can do this, groups are surprisingly easy to work with and everything is nice and basic. There's no money, you have points that you can spend on buildings or troups that can be refunded, you can't lose these points, but you can gain points depending on the mission. Story mode was a joy to go through with interesting situations, the escort missions were done right (They draw a path and tell you when they plan to start moving, just clear it out and secure the bases around it, done!) Basic but interesting situations with adapting hives that change constantly to keep them interesting (Counter attack mutation always made things slightly awkward when capturing a new base, slow down poison made my army of flamethrowers struggle to get to the fight etc). It's a simple game, but it doesn't need to be any more then that. Really enjoyed it- looking forward to the developers next game!

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Infested Planet is somewhat reminiscent of Starcraft, however there is no resource harvesting and construction of buildings and bases more straighforward. Since the player has to manage large enemy swarms coming from various directions, it is important to figure out where to place marines and equipment such as gun turrets in order to keep one swarm from advancing, while taking out another that is situated at a different location. The game is simple to understand and highly addictive. It does get repetitive when one plays it for long sessions, however it's always fun to get back to it after a day or so.

Posted: August 25, 2016
												This is a realtime strategy game with a capture and hold elements (a bit tower deffense). There are many upgrades for your soldiers with various buildings and deffense buildings. The Constantly overwhelming feeling gameplay has stayed entertaining till the end. It has a main story witch is not too hard not too long ~15h (sadly). As you play on harder lvl-s you have too multitask and micromanage soldiers and abilities to maximize your effort. This game has many game modes raid / survive / capture all / hunt aliens etc you can replay any map as you progress, even replay it for money if you stuck. There are boosters if you stuck at a different point in the storry or other game modes.I bought this while it was on sale, I say it was worth it, fun and entertraning game!

Posted: August 12, 2016
												Not the most complex of RTS games, Infested Planet does have just enough challenge to keep you interested. The bugs never stop coming, so you can't ever stop paying attention. It's BP system in place of an economy further livens things up - you can't sit back and build up your power, you're given all that you're going to get till you take some strategic points. You must suffice. It's really very satisfying. Don't be scared off by the tower-defense aspect, as it's not really a tower defence, it's squad management with good solid defence backing it up. You take a point, place a tower to protect one flank and protect the other by sending your mercenaries screaming back into the breach.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												This game is unique and familiar at the same time. It feels like a warcraft 3 map with only heroes. You have a team of 3-9 soldiers that will go against thousands of  enemies, literally. The enemies are simple melee at first but develop much deadlier abilities later in the game or even later on the same map. To counter this your team can change skills on the fly to adapt to any situation. Because of this the game now oddly feels like a first person shooter where you can change from invisibile assassin to close quarters shotgunner to sniper rifle and then to flamethrower in just 3 seconds leaving behind assassinated enemy heroes, dozens of dead spitting aliens a destroyed tower and a burning building including the enemies in it. There is no limit to the changes you can make, marines can change an unlimited number of times, buildings can be recycled getting the full resources back, research and upgrades can be sold back as well. The only limitation is that except plain marines everything else uses resources and thus the number of upgrades that you can have at the same time is limited. Thus it is very important to determine which upgrades you need at a certain point in time and establish a strategy before you jump into combat. The game also features a pause button which I rarely use as i prefer real time strategy over turn based mechanics.You gain resources for captuing enemy points and dragging resource crates back to the bases you own. You do not lose resources when losing a point so while the progress may be slow and incremental, you definetly can try new approaches if you get pushed back after a point capture.There is definetly replay values with random generated maps and a ladder system that shows how well you did on a map as compared to other players. There is also a weekly challenge and a nice story mode with additional mechanics.I definetly recommend the game.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I dismissed this as another entry in the tower defense genre, especially when combined with its middling metacritic score.  After watching a quick Youtube video it was made abundantly clear just how wrong I was!  You do have to fend off swarms of baddies, but more often than not you are juggling your resources and your 'towers' (turrets) are left behind to haplessly try to hold the tide back at key choke points...think the corridor sentries in Aliens.  Don't make the mistake of just glossing this one over before writing it off, it's one heck of a lot of frenetic fun and about as far removed from a traditional tower defense game as you can get.  The Steam trailer actually does this game a huge disservice, both by focusing on secondary aspects of combat and not giving anywhere near an accurate sense of the scope of how battles over the control points play out.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												This game is great, especially if you get it on sale. It's a great mix of rts and tower defense. It does ramp up in difficulty pretty quickly, but the main campaign never gets too difficult. It's mostly the side missions that are a lot harder, but never too difficult as to not see how to win eventually or after restarting. The campaign is about 10-14 hours depending on how many side missions you do. Skirmish mode adds endless more hours of enjoyment. Runs great too.

It's BP system in place of an economy further livens things up - you can't sit back and build up your power, you're given all that you're going to get till you take some strategic points. You must suffice. It's really very satisfying. Don't be scared off by the tower-defense aspect, as it's not really a tower defence, it's squad management with good solid defence backing it up. Posted: February 2, 2016
												My score: 9/10An enjoyable RTS. It's kind of like playing Starcraft against the zerg. I appreciate that there are different strategies that you can play, and there is no one set way of playing the game "right." The AI mutates, which means you have to change your strategy on the fly, and you are able to do so because you can change character class, and buildings on the spot. The game is fast-paced, and there's no resource collecting.Some problems with the game though is that it can be rubber-bandy. You take over one spot and another one gets taken over. You retake it, and the enemy regroups somewhere else... Another problem is that the 'tidying up' phase can be a bit drawn out. Not so bad that you're looking for one peasant hiding somewhere in the fog of war, but there's a point when you can say: "I won already, c'mon..."Pros:Various strategies work equally well.Fast-paced.Good variety of buildings and character classes.Feels good gunning down waves of aliens.No grinding or other time-consuming activities.Cons:The game is a bit short. But it has decent replay value.Graphics could be better.Controls are not as precise, or snappy as I would've liked.Excellent game, worthy of it's price tag, and an even better deal if on sale.

The animations look clean.The options menu is sufficiently complete.The balance between units is mostly reasonable progressing both through the campaign and during individual missions via "mutations".I'd recommend it if you are looking for a horde mode RTS.

												This was an excellent RTS game that due to the small team you're controlling feels more like a top-down action game almost. I'll admit that there are a few upgrades I didn't use often, and one or two that I didn't use at all, but for the most part the upgrades were all very unique. I recommend this game to anyone, and if it is under $10, it is a steal.

												I found infested planet to be a challanging and rewarding little game that kept me entertained for a few hours. The missions are not too long or short, and while there isn't a huge depth of strategy, you still need to be able to balance your forces, plan your attacks and be very prepared to react to enemy attacks. Some missions seem particularly challanging until you find the key approach. Very enjoyable, 7/10

Posted: August 12, 2016
												Not the most complex of RTS games, Infested Planet does have just enough challenge to keep you interested. The bugs never stop coming, so you can't ever stop paying attention. It's BP system in place of an economy further livens things up - you can't sit back and build up your power, you're given all that you're going to get till you take some strategic points. You must suffice. It's really very satisfying. Don't be scared off by the tower-defense aspect, as it's not really a tower defence, it's squad management with good solid defence backing it up. You take a point, place a tower to protect one flank and protect the other by sending your mercenaries screaming back into the breach.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Infested Planet is strategy game from independent developer Rocket Bear Games. Take charge of 5 veteran soldiers and fight an alien army of 100,000. It's all about striking hard and killing lots of squishy alien bugs. To do this, you get an arsenal of awesome weapons; from walking tanks with miniguns to field artillery, you're set to kick the aliens back down their slimy hole. Infested Planet is a deep strategy game, with plenty of replay value. The game comes with a random map generator, allowing you to play in a new place whenever you want. The aliens themselves mutate unpredictably, and you have to stay on your toes to defeat them. Flex your strategic mind and outsmart the alien menace.

												Fantastic game!!! Bought this after watching a review on youtube and was not disappointed. The random mutations of the enemy becomes a real challenge the further into a game you get. Bought the dlc a few days ago and it was an interesting direction to take the game to develop it further. Posted: November 5, 2016
												One of the most fun games that I own.I play Infested Planet a couple times every week.  I have played through the story mode several times and will probably do so again.  The weekly challenges give me all the reason I need to keep on coming back for more.  And now there is a campaing mode (sorta like Risk) which is just excellent!The tactical combat is incredibly satisfying.  The way you have to adapt to the ever evolving enemies makes for some of the best squad based combat I have ever played.  There are so many interesting combinations of units, reasearch and tech you can build... I am still discovering new ways to win.Infested Planet has been updated and improved so many times I have lost count.  It is years old and still the developer is still showing love for this unique gem of a game.I cannot recommend Infested Planet strongly enough.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												You should play this game if you're looking to play Starship Troopers: The Movie: The Video Game.Note - as the game progresses, and more capabilities are unlocked, it turns in to Starship Troopers: The Book: The Video Game.Seriously, just torrents of blood.Recent update added Ironman mode, making every loss a permanent reduction in your assets, demanding constant vigilance against risk and loss. It's awesome.Additionally, the new DLC for the Planetary Campaign promises engagaging strategic/tactical fun whenever you have some time to kill.I continue to recommend this game after 67 total hours of play. It's not just an indie gem, it's a gem, period.

Posted: November 21, 2016
												Do you like tactics? Buy this game.Do you like bug stomping? Buy this game.Do you like a constant escalation of power? Buy this game.Infested Planet is, at first glance, an average looking game, when in reality its an absolute blast to play. The main crux of enjoyment is from the enemies mutations, which in non-scripted settings, mean the enemy aliens are constantly varied and no two encounters feel the same. You'll always be fielding new tactics and combinations of upgrades to beat your opponents, especially on the harder difficulties which can be extremely unfair at times. Regardless, its an amazing womp if you only play the story missions, but I highly suggest trying out other gameplay modes as they spice the game up even further. Infested Planet is definitely worth your time if you're a fan of top-down tactic games.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												About 600 hours under my belt with this game.. which is ridiculous. What I love about this game is you can do a short game and then get back to work! Or play all day. It's strategic and tactical, problem-solving, and you get to lay waste to thousands of critters. The expansion is well worth it! The campaign is neat when you're first starting out, but I don't play it anymore. I really, really love the weekly challenges, getting to compete against other players for top scores.Get the expansion, after you get the game of course. It's an elegant game, well-done, small and powerful. It has immense replayability. Out of all the steam games I've bought, this is the only one I still play all the time after so long. Like I said, it has elegance. Highly recommended!And when you feel like you've mastered it, you can do custom games that seriously stack the odds against yourself. And then spend an hour or two desparately trying to win. Seriously, people, this is the best-valued game I've ever bought on steam. It's totally worth it.

Posted: October 17, 2016
												This game is really simple to play at first. But with progression, you unlock more weapons, buildings and tactics. This quickly makes the game more challenging, strategic and most importantly, fun.The graphics are simple but allows the display of large numbers of aliens on the screen at once without frame drops. The sound design is effective and the guns sound impactful. I didn't really notice the music; didn't leave any lasting impact.Storywise, nothing much to speak of. It provides the bare minimum for the player to go around killing aliens and their hives.Overall, I highly recommend this game. Great fun for a low cost.

Posted: January 24, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Real time strategy "Tower Defence" game.Interface/Menu/SettingsYou can play in fullscreen or windowed mode.There are many different resolution sizes.There is a music volume slidebar available.There is a sound volume slidebar available.Able to change the controls on your keyboard.You are able to disable the screen shake.Has skirmish mode, Story mode and DLC Campaign.About the game.You will play with a set of marines to take over the enemy hives and elimating them one by one. There are literally SWARMS of enemies which will constantly attack you and you have to hold them off or engage them to stop the alien swarm coming out of the hives. You are able to upgrade your marines with better weapons, making defensive or offensive buildings or support upgrades. Hives will get stronger and they will gain upgrades and buffs whenever they are getting closer and closer to defeat. Aliens may change their attack pattern way and attack you from a different angle. Enemies could get like shields, Regeneration, stronger Aliens and alot more. This is randomized. Marines that dies while they are equipped with a different weapons, will not make them drop their weapon. The respawn timer depends on the equipped weapon marine.Interesting story and has side missions.Random maps and Enemy Buffs.Defensive/offensive/support buildings. Upgradeable marines with different weapons during ingame.Could be repetitive but also addictive.Upgradable/unlockable perks and buffs, Permanently and during ingame.Interesting gameplay,Decent music.Easy controls.Other things.Aliens will choose+Find an alternate path to attack and surprise you. Which will mean you have to keep your eyes and stay focused on all times. You will never know if you get attacked from the back or a totally unexpected way. I like this idea and makes the alien more "random" and forces you to stay tuned. If you aren't doing this then the enemy could make a comeback and you will lose the game.-------------------I Give this game a 8/10

You control marines or towers to block and slowly take out enemy bugs. Unlocking marine upgrades or tower/base upgrades to allow you to eradiate bugs. Simple controls.Makes me think of a prison architect / alien swarm hybrid5/10. Buy when on sale.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												This game is great, especially if you get it on sale. It's a great mix of rts and tower defense. It does ramp up in difficulty pretty quickly, but the main campaign never gets too difficult. It's mostly the side missions that are a lot harder, but never too difficult as to not see how to win eventually or after restarting. The campaign is about 10-14 hours depending on how many side missions you do. Skirmish mode adds endless more hours of enjoyment. Runs great too.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I dismissed this as another entry in the tower defense genre, especially when combined with its middling metacritic score.  After watching a quick Youtube video it was made abundantly clear just how wrong I was!  You do have to fend off swarms of baddies, but more often than not you are juggling your resources and your 'towers' (turrets) are left behind to haplessly try to hold the tide back at key choke points...think the corridor sentries in Aliens.  Don't make the mistake of just glossing this one over before writing it off, it's one heck of a lot of frenetic fun and about as far removed from a traditional tower defense game as you can get.  The Steam trailer actually does this game a huge disservice, both by focusing on secondary aspects of combat and not giving anywhere near an accurate sense of the scope of how battles over the control points play out.

Some of the side ones have a random factor as well so you can replay then a bit.There are also skirmish and Weekly challenges modes that you can play too, so this is a solid purchase!

Posted: December 31, 2016
												Infested Planet is awesome! It plays like they combined the best parts of squad-based RTS and tower defense. Resource management and research are present but streamlined, so you can do more of what's really important: Getting your marines into the fight. The point costs for everything are extremely well balanced, I never found myself thinking that something was too expensive or too cheap. There's enough game modes to keep it interesting for a long time. Game play modes include skirmishes, where you to take and hold points; raids, where you have to take as many points as you can before the time runs out; survival mode, where they just keep coming and coming until you are finally overwhelmed; and a campaign that combines aspects of all of these modes. There's also a challenge map that changes weekly. I haven't finished the campaign or tried the planetary campaign yet, but so far my favorite game mode is survival. The DLC is also extremely fun. Some of the game modes mentioned above are added by it, and it also adds a few neat things for your marines to use. You don't need the DLC to enjoy the game, however. It stands by itself very well. The only downside I can think of for this game is that the music gets a bit repetitive at times, but that could be just because I am playing it so much. :DEverything considered, this game is very polished, a jewel. I cannot recommend it enough.

												The base game is super fun and addicting if you like RTS. The campaign DLC is fun at first because it makes you adapt and use abilities that you otherwise wouldn't, but the DLC campaign is too slow paced and gets old too fast. The regular game is easily worth full price, but only get the DLC on a steep discount

Posted: January 17
												It's decent fun. Maybe 7 or 8 out of 10. Simplistic mechanics and even if it looks like something out of a flashgame 8 years ago it plays out real nice. Solid time eater if you like this genre. Campaing isn't huge and content is limited. Without the DLC the game feels like it's missing something. In the end, you relize it's missing the DLC that contains the rest of the game, and a fairly big chunk of it. My only problem here is the price tag. 14,99€ is too much for the main game alone. Rocket Bear Games didn't publish the full game that it should be on purpose to sell the DLC later for that sweet sweet money. Planetary Campaing should have been part of the main game. Main game as it is now should be priced 9,99€. As for the DLC, you should get that as well. But it's too expensive. With the DLC the price tag should say 14,99€. Not 19,85€ as it is now. My advise is get it from sale when there's actual big discounts. It's not worth the current full price. Otherwise good game.

												This is a fantastic indie game.  Plays really well and is thoroughly enjoyable, shame there isn't even more after the aready awesome content updates!Play if you're a fan of starship troopers or any other alien bug squashing game for that matter.Great fun.

Posted: February 10
												Infested Planet is one of those gems you can play for years without getting bored. It's a tactical RTS where you fight against huge swarms of alien forces. Game mechanics are pretty unconventional. You constantly have to adapt to alien mutations. There's no way you could just overrun the enemy like in other RTS's. You really have to know your troops and even more important, know your enemy!10/10

Posted: February 11
												9/10 An excellent RTS that is very addictive and incredibly fun. Great campaign and skirmish modes with weekly challenges. The only thing I could wish for is multiplayer. Just buy it, you won't regret it. Highly recommended!

Posted: July 4, 2016
												Initially I disliked this alot.  ALOT. But after a bit of geting used to it, its actualy pretty fun. 07/10!If you like really fast paced RTS, fighting in multiple fronts at once, not needing to manage resorces and shouting "OH SH*T I DIDNT SEE THEY WERE COMING THAT WAY TOO!!" a lot you will like this.Or, if you are like me that likes more slower paced RTS, with more focus on macro/economy and less on "EVERYONE DIES!!!" and "no front line" kinda thing you can always play on easy and enjoy it.  :D lol
